\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Aug  2 23:21:20 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Jake
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Troop movement
\n`7CC`6: `7Varulv Duren Eliana
\n\n
Varulv, Duren and I briefly discussed a new option for\n
implementing troop movement in the new war system.  It\n
entails ripping out the existing 'meandering trails'\n
between major cities, and replacing them with straight-shot\n
zones coded to scale.  Because of the scaling, PCs and\n
troops could only move a few rooms per day, IC, so we'd\n
have to have OLC recognize outdoor terrain types (the\n
existing ones may be sufficient - not sure offhand), and\n
movement between these rooms would have to cost a lot of\n
endurance in code.  I think this eliminates all the problems\n
we have with the previously examined options, though it\n
does require some extra work.  Here's what we'd need:\n
\n
Eli and V, please look at your milage estimates between\n
cities and decide how many rooms we'd need to place\n
between existing cities (those zones would remain untouched).\n
My initial guess is that something like 3 code rooms\n
would be about as much as a marching army can handle\n
per day - much more, and we'd have to code way too many\n
rooms, and much less and people who accidently stepped\n
out of a city would be unable to get back to it in a\n
reasonable amount of time :p Once we get an idea of how\n
many rooms we'd need, we'll decide if this is doable.\n
\n
Provided the room numbers aren't too great, we put together\n
a set of generic room descs for the major terrain types.\n
We'd repeat them over and over, and make all zones out of\n
these generic descs.  We could even do this to make a\n
'template' zone, copy if into multiple zones, and then\n
connect the dots around the edges and add important\n
features as necessary.\n
\n
This would allow us to really enforce code=IC in all\n
instances I can think of, and allows for a maximum of\n
PC interaction with traveling and camped armies.  We\n
can implement scouting, sneaking away from cities, trade\n
embargoes and IC mailing this way, and it'd all be\n
totally representable IC.  Codewise, as far as the zones\n
go, the only major adjustments need to be the movement\n
costs to PCs and troops depending on the terrain type,\n
which obviously has to be hard coded.  I don't think that's\n
a big deal, is it, Duren? I think this about hits the\n
major points of this.  Zones should be giant squares, also,\n
to allow for people skirting around army bodies and the\n
like (everybody needs to be able to move in all 4 cardinal\n
directions all the time, though moving through dense forest\n
should be harder than following the trail).  We'll just\n
add trails to connect the cities through the template zones,\n
and as we get more players, we'll rewrite the descs to\n
make them better, down the road.\n
\n
Thoughts?\n
-Nico\n

embargoes and IC mailing this way, and it'd all be\n
totally representable IC.  Codewise, as far as the zones\n
go, the only major adjustments need to be the movement\n
costs to PCs and troops depending on the terrain type,\n
which obviously has to be hard coded.  I don't think that's\n
a big deal, is it, Duren? I think this about hits the\n
major points of this.  Zones should be giant squares, also,\n
to allow for people skirting around army bodies and the\n
like (everybody needs to be able to move in all 4 cardinal\n
directions all the time, though moving through dense forest\n
should be harder than following the trail).  We'll just\n
add trails to connect the cities through the template zones,\n
and as we get more players, we'll rewrite the descs to\n
make them better, down the road.\n
\n
Thoughts?\n
-Nico\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Aug  2 23:21:20 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Jake
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Troop movement
\n`7CC`6: `7Varulv Duren Eliana
\n\n
Varulv, Duren and I briefly discussed a new option for\n
implementing troop movement in the new war system.  It\n
entails ripping out the existing 'meandering trails'\n
between major cities, and replacing them with straight-shot\n
zones coded to scale.  Because of the scaling, PCs and\n
troops could only move a few rooms per day, IC, so we'd\n
have to have OLC recognize outdoor terrain types (the\n
existing ones may be sufficient - not sure offhand), and\n
movement between these rooms would have to cost a lot of\n
endurance in code.  I think this eliminates all the problems\n
we have with the previously examined options, though it\n
does require some extra work.  Here's what we'd need:\n
\n
Eli and V, please look at your milage estimates between\n
cities and decide how many rooms we'd need to place\n
between existing cities (those zones would remain untouched).\n
My initial guess is that something like 3 code rooms\n
would be about as much as a marching army can handle\n
per day - much more, and we'd have to code way too many\n
rooms, and much less and people who accidently stepped\n
out of a city would be unable to get back to it in a\n
reasonable amount of time :p Once we get an idea of how\n
many rooms we'd need, we'll decide if this is doable.\n
\n
Provided the room numbers aren't too great, we put together\n
a set of generic room descs for the major terrain types.\n
We'd repeat them over and over, and make all zones out of\n
these generic descs.  We could even do this to make a\n
'template' zone, copy if into multiple zones, and then\n
connect the dots around the edges and add important\n
features as necessary.\n
\n
This would allow us to really enforce code=IC in all\n
instances I can think of, and allows for a maximum of\n
PC interaction with traveling and camped armies.  We\n
can implement scouting, sneaking away from cities, trade\n
embargoes and IC mailing this way, and it'd all be\n
totally representable IC.  Codewise, as far as the zones\n
go, the only major adjustments need to be the movement\n
costs to PCs and troops depending on the terrain type,\n
which obviously has to be hard coded.  I don't think that's\n
a big deal, is it, Duren? I think this about hits the\n
major points of this.  Zones should be giant squares, also,\n
to allow for people skirting around army bodies and the\n
like (everybody needs to be able to move in all 4 cardinal\n
directions all the time, though moving through dense forest\n
should be harder than following the trail).  We'll just\n
add trails to connect the cities through the template zones,\n
and as we get more players, we'll rewrite the descs to\n
make them better, down the road.\n
\n
Thoughts?\n
-Nico\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Aug  2 23:28:32 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Jake
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Memo below
\nHey, thought you'd be interested in this.  We're thinking\n
about replacing all the unscaled zones between cities with\n
zones that better represent travel time, for the war code.\n
They'd be square zones of generic descs, but we'd add higher\n
movement costs to represent traveling greater distances\n
per room (armies would only be able to go a few outdoor\n
rooms per IC day).  The zones would be square so you could\n
hack your way through any direction, but it'd obviously\n
be fastest/easiest to follow the trails.  Since presumably\n
nobody would RP in these areas for the most part, we'd\n
just make basic descs and use them over and over again.\n
We could make a template zone of 10x10 rooms, and just\n
copy it into different zone numbers, then connect them\n
around the edges and place in any absolutely necessary\n
trails or landmarks.  The staff mail is forwarded below.\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Tue Aug 10 15:19:00 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Jake
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Update: Building Task Force
\n`7CC`6: `7Beonca Ranulf Boris Varulv Eliana
\n\n
Ok, we're each on the building team for this - we're jokingly\n
calling it the 'Meanding Trails" project.  As of right now,\n
here's the plan:\n
\n
Varulv and Boris are drawing up a grid map of Randland.  We're\n
going to use that to establish what scale to use, soon as they're\n
done.\n
\n
Duren says that there is no max we need to be concerned with\n
on the number of zones we're adding.  However, we will be removing\n
(not deleting!) the out of date zones that no one uses, because\n
they are sucking up a lot of our memory.  We'll keep them backed\n
up (they already are) so we can recycle some of them at a later date.\n
\n
After we establish how many zones we're going to need to map\n
Randland, we'll be doing the following:\n
*disconnect all the existing 'travel' zones that nobody\n
uses - trails, wierd areas, etc.  We'll disconnect the\n
exits and then delete their entries from the index file\n
so they aren't loaded when we reboot anymore.\n
*leave existing cities and RP centers as they are, and reconnect\n
them to our new zones\n
*the new zones will be square (10 rooms x 10 rooms).  We'll create\n
a template zone that we'll just copy over and over again onto\n
the grid, then connect the edges so that the entire world exists\n
as a generic grid.  Then, we'll go through and overwrite generic\n
descs with specific ones.\n
*generic descs will be overwritten with specific ones - this means\n
we'll be placing the major roads and rivers first, followed by\n
landmarks, and someday we'll be able to rewrite all descs to\n
make them unique again, as well as add mobs (some day we'll\n
have scripting in place for most mobs).\n
\n
We'll decide how many zones we're going to put in between cities\n
based on the map Varulv and Boris are drawing up.  This will\n
probably be the last 'big' building project we ever do, until\n
we put in special procedure mobs.\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Sat Aug 14 12:31:54 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Jake
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Ubermap
\n`7CC`6: `7Varulv Beonca Boris Ranulf Eliana
\n\n
I spent some time working on zone estimates for the continental\n
map, and came up with two options for zone size.\n
\n
Option 1:\n
Tar Valon is 25 rooms north, 9 rooms east of Caemlyn.  This\n
gives a movement rate of 5 rooms per day for troop mobs.  By\n
comparison, Aringill is 10 rooms east and 1 room south of Caemlyn.\n
This makes the continental map 13 zones wide and 11 zones high,\n
or 143 areas (14300 descriptions).  In other words, you can\n
walk north across the entire continent in 105 rooms, and east\n
for 130 rooms.\n
\n
Option 2:\n
Tar Valon is 38 rooms north, 14 rooms east of Caemlyn.  Troops\n
move 8 rooms per day (Aringill would be a trip of 17 rooms, in\n
this case).  The continent would be 20 zones wide by 16 zones\n
high, giving an area of 320 zones and 32000 descriptions.\n
\n
What do you guys think? Any smaller scale than option 1, and\n
troop mobs will only be moving a couple rooms a day, which\n
gets lame for tactics and then there's just plain not enough\n
rooms from one end of the world to the other.  Any larger\n
scale than option 2, and we pass the point of getting old\n
and having the internet be outdated before we finish.\n
\n
I vote option 1.  It's most doable workwise and still gives\n
us tons of rooms to work with.  However, option 2 is perfectly\n
feasible, too, but it's the upper end of what we can do provided\n
lots of us work on it.\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Wed Aug 18 19:46:29 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Jake
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Change of plan
\nHey, after we hit some snags with scaling with the current\n
continent map, we decided to up the size and make it larger.\n
Cormac's agreed to as much work on it as we need (he said\n
he's willing to put in whatever time it takes cuz he feels\n
it's important to do this right, so *shrug*).  The new vnums\n
for the zones are gonna be 0 - 729.  We're keeping what we\n
coded so far, and just adding to it.\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Wed Aug 18 21:44:33 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Jake
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Update on the continent
\n`7CC`6: `7Mat Beonca Eliana Ranulf Henry
\n\n
Ok, Caemlyn and Aringill are both marked out on the map\n
and connected by the road (which is identified by titles\n
in the rooms, but no descs yet).  From room 44043 (what\n
will be the east gate of Caemlyn), it's 2 e, 1 s, east til\n
you hit the west gate of Aringill.  Both Aringill and\n
Caemlyn occupy 9 squares of the big map (3 rooms x 3 rooms).\n
\n
What we need are:\n
Descs for the road.\n
Descs for the rooms immediately surrounding Caemlyn.  Maybe\n
a small scattering of houses/farms?\n
Somebody to go through the current list of zones (show zone)\n
on the live port and pick out which ones are total junk,\n
which ones we can steal descs from and which we'll be\n
importing exactly as is (like Caemlyn).\n
About 500 more zones. :p Hopefully Eli and I can do these\n
before we get old and die.\n
That's about it for the moment.  Beonca, I think I need\n
your email again - I don't have it saved on this machine.\n
Everybody else, I'm sending you the updated map now.\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Thu Aug 19 19:52:11 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Ranulf
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Thought
\nHey, instead of bothering with lockers for dropping cities\n
why not create an object in the zone with keywords city, (and which one)\n
that way where city works, as does where (name). Also, if you put it to load into the\n
zedit, it'll always show up.\n
\n
Also, I had an idea of how to place smaller homesteads. I've only been using the new 'enter' and 'climb' object code this far for secret rooms.\n
at this risk of exposing that we have this code. We can start making smaller hamlets, roadside inns, etc, as this sorta thign.\n
Mac\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Tue Sep 14 09:25:34 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Sitrep
\n`7CC`6: `7Ranulf Duren Serai
\n\n
Hey guys, I'm around but since this place has been dead I've\n
been spending my free time in the real world.  Duren said that\n
he thinks we should keep working on our projects as we get time,\n
but  I mostly feel that I'm gonna keep doing what I'm doing until\n
we get a small group of people together with some more free time\n
than anybody's had lately.  In the meantime, if you guys want\n
to pick at stuff we need, here's the list:\n
\n
Serai, on creation, with the last version of the talent lists we\n
sent.  We'll do the final version of those further down the road.\n
\n
Duren, on the OLC-style interface for bodypart lists.\n
\n
Mac, on the continent.  For my part, I'll add some more zones\n
and I guess the other priority (as always) is combat.\n
\n
These all need to be finished before we can get the mud on its\n
feet again.  I just don't want to be a solo act anymore - but as\n
soon as you guys are up for some more activity and we can\n
beat on these projects as a group, I'll be here.  Lemme know\n
what you wanna do.\n
\n
-Nico (and /don't/ send replies to Nico.  Mail Jake. *glare Mac* :p)\n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Wed Oct 20 15:59:09 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Caemlyn
\n`7CC`6: `7Rhiannon Shai'tan Varulv
\n\n
I think Maelyn and B are talking things out so I'm\n
just mailing us for now.  The first part of the\n
project is to finish getting Caemlyn and Aringill\n
cleaned up, linked to the new world map, and re-\n
descripting the surrounding countryside.  I'll do\n
the location stuff so we know exactly what rooms to\n
link between the existing cities and the new map,\n
so if you guys wouldn't mind, we need somebody to\n
go through Caemlyn and Aringill and decide what to\n
keep, and to remove what you don't want and to update/\n
pretty up what you don't like.  Aringill has extra\n
rooms in its zone that aren't part of the city, and\n
they need to be removed.  Also, starting to write\n
descs for the road that connects them would be great.\n
I think it's about 17 rooms long.\n
\n
I'm gonna be uberbusy tonight, but I'll do the shell\n
linking real soon - won't take me long, I just need\n
to get time between classes to do it.\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Oct 25 06:18:45 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Building
\nHey Mae, I have no idea where things stand with you after last week,\n
but if you're interested I've put together a project on the builderport\n
that we need help on, if you're interested.  Some others volunteered\n
but I was hoping you'd head it up, since it might actually get done\n
that way :p It's the Caemlyn/Aringill area of the map - soon as Boris\n
finishes his script it'll be ready to hand off to you.  Wanna drop me\n
a line and let me know?\n
\n
Thanks,\n
Retired in Maryland\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Thu Oct 28 09:44:25 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Re: building shit.
\nMostly it's writing descs for the countryside surrounding\n
Caemlyn and Aringill, and the road that connects the\n
two.  What I did was rip out the old trails and replace\n
them with a big rectangular area (30 rooms east-west,\n
10 rooms north-south).  The entire city of Caemlyn\n
is inserted into one room towards the west side\n
of this big map, and the entire city of Aringill is\n
inserted into one room on the east side.  If you're\n
interested, the descs are generic and need to be\n
changed so that the road between the two cities\n
doesn't have the same desc as the surrounding countryside,\n
like it currently does, and as you/anybody else\n
gets time, the rooms around the two cities should\n
be updated too.  The vast majority (something like\n
1200) exits are connected and correct, but Boris\n
is reloading the whole map so the breaks between\n
the zones need to be connected around the east-west\n
edge, and the city exits need to be reconnected.\n
I already wrote up all the vnums and links - I\n
just need somebody to go through and punch them\n
in.\n
\n
This has been a fun project when you're not\n
working on it by yourself all the time.  If you can\n
talk a friend or two into doing it with you, it's\n
more fun than being on the live port most of the time.\n
You'll see why when you start running circuits\n
around Caemlyn and using the new ethereal marker\n
system to bounce between cities :p It's kinda funny.\n
\n
Anyway, if you're up for it, lemme know.\n
-Nico, who almost died last night cuz he really\n
is totally allergic to beer now.\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Thu Nov  4 09:39:51 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 K
\nK.  I can't do it today but tomorrow I probably can.  Help me harrass Duren or\n
Boris into fixing the raid bug, and Boris into finishing the script.  In case\n
they go 'what's the raid bug', it:\n
\n
Crashes the BP and corrupts the zone you were rediting.\n
Has something to do with raid and redit.\n
Crashes when you redit a room with the 'raid' flag on.\n
Crashes when you redit a room with a raided desc that has\n
somehow gotten corrupted (when you type redit, you'll notice\n
that suddenly the raided desc is all fubared - crash follows\n
shortly after).\n
Requires the reboot file to be removed and the corrupted zone\n
to be either removed or reloaded from scratch in order to reboot\n
properly.  Otherwise, it goes into a recursive loop and\n
monopolizes envy's server.\n
\n
There's only limited stuff we can do on the BP until these two\n
things get done.  Soon as they are done, though, it won't take\n
much to get lots of the rest of things finishes.\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Fri Nov  5 16:40:37 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 *SLAP*
\n`7CC`6: `7Hale Duren
\n\n
For crap's sake bro, we've gone over this so many times I can't believe\n
you're asking me again.  It happens for a bunch of reasons - mess with\n
redit in any room where the raid desc is enabled, or just edit a raided\n
desc in redit until it crashes.  It happens pretty much no matter how you\n
screw with raid, but I suspect it's directly linked to a problem with redit.\n
It's pretty easy to make happen - just about any way you play with, edit\n
or adjust raid causes first obvious corruption, then an inevitable crash\n
shortly after.  The crash can't recover until the zone (now corrupted) is\n
either restored or removed, and sometimes you have to remove the\n
reboot.txt file (1 in 15 times or so, in my experience - I'd forgotten all\n
about it til you found it this time).\n
\n
There are no error messages in game, and I can't remember off the\n
top of my head what syslog says.  The first evidence is usually file\n
corruption - the room you're working in starts to look like random text\n
mixed in with spliced room descs.   The crash happens at different\n
times - sometimes it's as soon as you type redit in a corrupted room,\n
sometimes it's while you're rediting the room (as you work thru the\n
menus all the sudden the raid desc is messed up, crash follows shortly).\n
I don't think it's ever crashed when I was saving the room, though,\n
always either in redit or after I'd redited the room, after obvious\n
corruption has occured.  It's real easy to get to happen, just do anything\n
to the raid desc and redit repeatedly until it goes down.  It affects any\n
room you do this to - adding new raided descs causes it, playing with\n
existing raided descs causes it, turning the raid desc on and then\n
rediting that room causes it.  Also, if you try and reboot without removing\n
or restoring the corrupted zone, it can't recover and we just eat up\n
all of the CPU until envy goes down :p\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n\n
I looked at your zone, B - except for the crash Serai reported shortly\n
after, the zedit new command (is that what you used?) did create all\n
four files for the zone and it updates the index files properly.  The only\n
thing I noticed was that your versions of 3.obj and 3.mob didn't have\n
the exact same data as our original accepted 'template' files for blank\n
zones, so I overwrote yours with those but I don't think it should have\n
made a difference.  As far as the crash goes, no idea.  I did a copyover\n
after playing with the files and it came up just fine.  I renamed your\n
zone on the show zone list, and it saved fine.  It's not lagging now,\n
so I dunno - it may have just been your link. *shrugs* You guys can\n
try and create zones this way if you like - if it keeps crashing, then\n
we know there's a bug in it still, but it looks ok.\n
\n

a list together.  It's kinda less tedious to do them in groups.\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Tue Nov  9 14:45:32 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Sudo and ubermap
\n`7CC`6: `7Boris Duren
\n\n
Re: Sudo - k. :p\n
\n
For the world files, I looked 'em over carefully and there's a\n
couple things.  Firstly (not your fault), the template file you\n
had was missing something, so I added it and resaved it as\n
200.wld.  When we do this for real, use 200.wld as your template.\n
\n
Secondly, your loop for file creation appears to be off in a\n
couple of minor ways.  For instance, row A needs to consist\n
of znums 200-225, not 200-224.  Row B is 230 - 255, not 231\n
to 244.  Every row is 26 rooms, and columns start at #00,\n
#30, and #60 for #'s 2 - 8.  The last row is just 900 - 925.\n
\n
Also, don't save 'em as .wld.bak files in the final version - they'll\n
have to be straight .wld files.  We'll also need the accompanying\n
index file (see  /../builderport/lib/world/wld/index) with all\n
the new zone numbers added.\n
\n
For the remaining file types (.obj, .mob and .zon), use the\n
template 240 (not 200).  240.obj, 240.mob and 240.zon will\n
work for all, and we need them numbered exactly the same\n
as the .wld files.  Also, each of those 3 file types has an\n
accompanying index file that's exactly the same as the\n
world index file except every reference of .wld is changed to\n
.obj, .mob or .zon, respectively.\n
\n
Otherwise, this is perfect.  Just need you to use the new\n
200.wld template and to get the loop working correctly, and\n
we're gold.  The text in the files is 100%.  Nice work :>\n
\n
-Nic\n

\n`7CC`6: `7Boris Duren
\n\n
Re: Sudo - k. :p\n
\n
For the world files, I looked 'em over carefully and there's a\n
couple things.  Firstly (not your fault), the template file you\n
had was missing something, so I added it and resaved it as\n
200.wld.  When we do this for real, use 200.wld as your template.\n
\n
Secondly, your loop for file creation appears to be off in a\n
couple of minor ways.  For instance, row A needs to consist\n
of znums 200-225, not 200-224.  Row B is 230 - 255, not 231\n
to 244.  Every row is 26 rooms, and columns start at #00,\n
#30, and #60 for #'s 2 - 8.  The last row is just 900 - 925.\n
\n
Also, don't save 'em as .wld.bak files in the final version - they'll\n
have to be straight .wld files.  We'll also need the accompanying\n
index file (see  /../builderport/lib/world/wld/index) with all\n
the new zone numbers added.\n
\n
For the remaining file types (.obj, .mob and .zon), use the\n
template 240 (not 200).  240.obj, 240.mob and 240.zon will\n
work for all, and we need them numbered exactly the same\n
as the .wld files.  Also, each of those 3 file types has an\n
accompanying index file that's exactly the same as the\n
world index file except every reference of .wld is changed to\n
.obj, .mob or .zon, respectively.\n
\n
Otherwise, this is perfect.  Just need you to use the new\n
200.wld template and to get the loop working correctly, and\n
we're gold.  The text in the files is 100%.  Nice work :>\n
\n
-Nic\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Tue Nov  9 19:00:23 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Boris
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Areafiles
\nCheck  /areafile_test .  It should be there by the time you log on, it's uploading\n
to my directory now.  I went ahead and fixed the loops, and checked the numbers.\n
It should be right.  I didn't check out the new 200.wld template, so if I missed\n
and instance of the vnum, let me know.  Other than that, I've included the .zon,\n
.obj, and .mob files as well as .wld, each in their own directory.  All that\n
remains is for you to check them for correctness, and then fix the index files.\n
The index file is in each directory.  You go in there and add whichever zones\n
we're keeping aside from the ones I just made, and then go ahead and copy the\n
files over.  I've made them in .bak format so there's no risk of overwriting\n
(I think for example we have a new and good 300 area that shouldn't get over-\n
written.)  All you have to do is mv (or cp) *.bak * and it should do them.\n
That's why it's 200.wld.bak, for example\n
Boris\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Wed Nov 10 14:38:45 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Wee
\nDude, we're soooo close.  All four file types are 100% - I\n
used diff -u on each of them against my originals and they\n
came out perfectly.  Your file creation loop is still wrong\n
tho - one row out of every 100 znums is short by 10 zones.\n
\n
For the second row, it should create files for 230-255, and it\n
only does it for 230-245.  The index file is also missing\n
these 10 zones for every hundred znums.  That is - your first\n
and third row are fine, but your second row (and every\n
respective row beginning at #30 needs to go to #55 so that\n
it's 25 rooms wide.  Currently they all stop at #45).\n
\n
Also - don't save them as .bak files, seriously.  Duren doesn't\n
know of a way to mass-convert them to just .zon or whatever\n
files and neither do I, so the BP won't recognize them at all.\n
Don't worry about overwriting - the zone you mean is zone 3, not\n
300.  There is no overlap between what you're uploading and\n
what's currently there that doesn't need to get overwritten.\n
Just leave 'em as .mob and .wld, etc.\n
\n
:p\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Wed Nov 10 15:15:31 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Elaena
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Wolfkin Seeker.
\nI plan to seek the Gleemen...but only after my background has been\n
Approved by you.\n
\n
Elaena Harshare grew up in the southern part of Saldaea, for the better half \n
of eighteen years of her life. She had a mostly normal life her father Darmon \n
was a farmer of one of Saldaea's famous crops the ice pepper, as well as a \n
little bit of hunting for furs for his wife. Her mother Diedeadra was a \n
seamstress, she took the few furs that Elaena's father got and made them into \n
warm clothing to help the family out as much as possible during the harsh \n
winter months. But this life was not for Elaena she never picked up on any of \n
the sewing that her mother tried so hard to teach her. Instead she spent most \n
of her life following her dad around, and trying hard to pick up every bit \n
about hunting that she could, from the time she was eight till she was about \n
thirteen she wanted to be a hunter and sell furs for a living, of course her \n
being an only child, and her father who had always wanted to ahve a boy allowed \n
this, but only when her mother could not discover what he was teaching thier \n
daughter. But all that changed once she was able to have some freedom, and she \n
began to see the world, the local inn mostly, she liked to go there and talk to \n
the local hunters. But one day as young minds are feeble, she found a profession \n
that she truly wanted she wanted to be a Gleemen. She watched how the Gleemen \n
attracted so much attention, and drew large crowds, so she began to observe the \n
man's actions as much as she could. After the Gleemen left town Elaena began to \n
pursue this talent as much as she could, she began to learn how to juggle the \n
knives that her father gave her, and then also picked up on playing the harp, \n
and she began to play for the local inns. Her family soon found out what she was \n
doing, and both mother and father were disappointed in her for even thoguh they \n
held different views on how to raise her and what she should become, they both \n
agreed that the life of a Gleemen was not a life that they wanted for thier child. \n
Elaena, angry with her parents, and wishing to find a gleemen to apprentice under \n
to further master her skills set out to find a real Gleeman so that she could \n
apprentice and become a full Gleeman. \n
\n
On her journey she spent a lot of nights camped out in the woods, and one night \n
when it was time for her to put up camp she saw a camp fire already made up. \n
Introducing herself to her strange company she told her life story to the man \n
and woman in the campsite, and then they told theirs. Apparently they were both \n
Wolfkin, and lived in the wilderness with wolves, Elaena thought this a very odd \n
thing, but kept listening, because perhaps someday she could tell a story about \n
it. It is that night that she was told that she could speak to the wolves herself, \n
she of course didn't believe them, but upon thier instruction however doubtful she \n
was about it, she did make an atempt to 'feel' for the wolves as they called it. \n
That is when she found herself able to 'feel' a wolf at the edge of the camp that \n
she had not seen there before, this wolf shortly after her discovery, entered the \n
camp, to share dinner with the strange couple. Freaked out by the encounter Elaena \n
fled from the camp just as soon as she could, despite the couples warnings that \n
she should stay with them, to learn more about her 'gift'. The wolves aptly named \n
her RushingWind for this, for her music that she played upon her harp reminded them \n
of the music the wind made when it flowed through the woods, and her quick escape\n
from them only added to this new name they had for her. Still in pursuit of her \n
dream she came to Caemlyn, but by time she arrived at Caemlyn her eyes were already \n
starting to change, and despite the strange couples warnings about her soon to be \n
changing eye color Elaena, has discovered that in the cities there are no wolves to \n
torture her thoughts, so now she hides in Caemlyn away from the wolves where she can \n
persue her dreams.\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--

\n`7CC`6: `7Boris Duren
\n\n
Hey, I'm trying to reestablish the BP after uploading all of\n
Boris' files, and syslog is getting hung up on something\n
I haven't seen before - "Loading zone files" is the last\n
thing it tries to do before stalling.  I broke the BP down to\n
just a few zones (including the critical boot ones for\n
start rooms), and made new index files so that it should\n
boot with just the bare minimum of stuff - only it's\n
doing the exact same thing.  Any ideas what it means\n
by 'loading zone files' if it's not referring to the index?\n
\n
Also, Duren, you said there were backups of zones\n
made daily.  Can I get at the Nov 11 or Nov 12 (early)\n
backups of zone 3 on the BP? I can't find them.\n
\n
-Nico, sighing as usual\n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Fri Nov 12 18:56:36 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Beonca
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Kaelin's bg

\nKaelin Severash grew up in a region at war the second son of a minor Andoran border lord. Born and raised on his father's estate in southern Andor near the border with Murandy. Frequent border clashes between Murandy and Andor meant his childhood was spent in preparation for one day aiding his father and elder brother in the defense of Andor. \n
\n

After reaching adulthood, he spent most of his time leading a small scouting squad for his father during clashes with Murandian border troops and mercenary units. He lacked experience, but was carried through by a thirst for knowledge and the aid of a veteran subcommander. Engaging in numerous minor skirmishes against small enemy forces, he developed a knack for small-unit tactics in closed terrain. He also made a few kills, though all were at long-range... and it wasn't until much later and many hundred leagues away that he killed an opponent up-close (mainly because he was not a very good melee fighter and not ashamed to admit it.) \n
\n

During a surprise assault against the family's estate by mercenaries in the employ of a Murandian Border Lord, he found himself in an upstairs hallway, running towards the armoury to retrieve his crossbow. Rounding a corner, he came upon a mercenary about to attack his younger sister. She seemed to have every intention of standing her ground, though armed only with knives against the mercenary's sword. As he ran to her aid, he thought he was going to be too late... but he was wrong. An unseen hand grasped the mercenary and threw him with considerable force against a wall, breaking his back. At the time, it seemed that Angel had manifested the ability to channel.\n
\n

His father could not leave the estate in the wake of the attack, and his elder brother Rei was required to aid in the planning of retribution against the Murandians. With ten picked men at his disposal, Kaelin was tasked with escorting his sister to Tar Valon to be presented to the White Tower. After an uneventful journey they arrived at the Shining Walls. The first Aes Sedai they met, a Red as it happened, seemed rather excited at finding a girl who could channel, and tested her there and then. Angel passed the test\n
she could channel, and was inroled into the White Tower. \n
\n

Returning home to his father's estate he lived and worked, knowing he'd never be the Lord of his father's lands, but still. It was about five years later that the Severash family recieved word that Angel had been tested for Accepted and failed the test resulting in the loss of her life. \n
\n

Anger filled Kaelin, how could those.. witches kill his sister and not care about it. His family was devistated, Kaelin took his father aside, and spoke admetnly about wanting to do something with his life. "I want to join the Children of the Light." His father nodded and gave him his blessing. Kaelin went to Amadica to train in the ways of the Light, he swiftly rose in ranks\n
\n

Tall for and Andoran, Kaelin stands six foot in height, and weighs 190 pounds. His long hair is redish brown in colour, leaving it held back in a leather cord he hides a scar on the back of his neck. His eyes are a dark colour of brown, almost black. They are hard and intense as he peers around him. Kaelin's face is rounded, giving him a handsome feature, when conbined with his dark hair and eyes.\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Fri Nov 12 18:56:36 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Beonca

she could channel, and was inroled into the White Tower. \n
\n

Returning home to his father's estate he lived and worked, knowing he'd never be the Lord of his father's lands, but still. It was about five years later that the Severash family recieved word that Angel had been tested for Accepted and failed the test resulting in the loss of her life. \n
\n

Anger filled Kaelin, how could those.. witches kill his sister and not care about it. His family was devistated, Kaelin took his father aside, and spoke admetnly about wanting to do something with his life. "I want to join the Children of the Light." His father nodded and gave him his blessing. Kaelin went to Amadica to train in the ways of the Light, he swiftly rose in ranks\n
\n

Tall for and Andoran, Kaelin stands six foot in height, and weighs 190 pounds. His long hair is redish brown in colour, leaving it held back in a leather cord he hides a scar on the back of his neck. His eyes are a dark colour of brown, almost black. They are hard and intense as he peers around him. Kaelin's face is rounded, giving him a handsome feature, when conbined with his dark hair and eyes.\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Sat Nov 13 12:55:32 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Jake
\n`7Subj`6:`7 BP
\n`7CC`6: `7Beonca Nenae Syrah
\n\n
The BP's back up with the ubermap fully imported.  It took a fair\n
bit of doing, because the number of rooms was bigger than circle\n
was coded for, so Duren and I had to go through and upgrade\n
everything - thank him, cuz no way I could have gotten it to work\n
by myself.  Incidently, Marek's a moron.  His code was some of\n
the most annoying, and it doesn't work right anyways.\n
\n
B, I'm real sorry, but I lost any changes you made to zone 3\n
between Wednesday when I imported it and Thursday when\n
I started upgrading the BP.  I was able to restore it to the version\n
that's on there now (same as the live version), but apparently\n
the daily backup system does not do anything for the BP.  I'm\n
sorry!\n
\n
We can do the next two stages of the project at the same time - I'm\n
going to continue to port over cities and zones as Syrah identifies\n
the keepers.  Currently, Caemlyn and Aringill are in, as well as\n
some essential zones that the BP won't run without, and that's it.\n
I'll be bringing over TV, Cairhien, and other major zones ASAP.\n
Syrah, any other zones you see that're keepers, recommendations\n
are helpful and would speed things up as you get time.\n
\n
At the same time I'm doing this, Syrah can be overseeing the\n
first real 'builder' phase of the project, where you guys link Caemlyn\n
and Aringill into their zones, and add in the descs of the surrounding\n
countrysides.  I sent Syrah a detailed writeup on how to do all of\n
this.  It includes vnums and specific instructions on exactly what\n
goes where and what to change.  Mort builders can do any of it.\n
The descs need to be appropriate to the color coded terrain map I\n
sent Syrah, and most importantly, the descs for the road between\n
Caemlyn and Aringill need to be changed from their current generic\n
desc to unique road descs.  All of this is written out much better\n
in the files I sent.\n
\n
Nenae and Beonca, you guys can continue your inns and newbie\n
zone - I'm very sorry about anything I lost.\n
\n
I should stress that this is a project that absolutely anybody can\n
handle - no real building is required anymore, since all the zones\n
are designed and linked.  All it needs is people, preferrably a\n
group of them, to go in and write better descs for each of the\n
existing rooms around the cities.  We're not going to do this for\n
the entire continent - right now, we're on Caemlyn and Aringill,\n
and when I import the other major cities, we'll do them similarly.\n
Any questions, feel free to beep me.  Thank Boris and Duren\n
for a hell of a job - our world isn't just bigger than other circle muds\n
now, it's a whole version ahead of them codewise. :p\n
\n
-Nico\n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Nov 22 13:27:12 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Kylriak
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Kylriak's Background
\nMutt. That is the best word to describe the heritage of\n
Kylriak bor Dravyn. Born of mixed blood, his parents own\n
ancestry lost through their ancestors mercantile travels,\n
Kylriak can lay no claim to any specific nation. He is\n
an outcast, a wanderer often looked at with strange eyes\n
for his oft times labeled strange behavior.\n
\n
Born aboard a merchant coach, tended for the first years\n
of his life by an overly protective mother, a demanding\n
yet understanding father, and a host of guards, Kylriak\n
was indeed an odd child. Too many questions were his forte,\n
and never an answer seemed to satisfy the youth. He learned\n
his geography through experience, the difference between\n
accents and dialects on both national and local scales,\n
although much was forgotten as he aged. Tarabon to Shienar,\n
Saldaea to Mayene, and all within he traversed aside from\n
the Caralain Grass and Black Hills. The Hills of Kintara\n
and Haddon's Mirk also were left unexplored and untraveled\n
by the youth and his family, instead remaining upon the\n
roads that hinged upon trade. Again forgotten as they years\n
passed him by.\n
\n
Life continued, boring and routine, and despite his parents\n
best efforts to drive him to do something with his life,\n
he refrained. Not once did he take up the blade, even at\n
his father's urging. Not once did he learn to balance sums\n
more than needed on a common level, nor did any interest\n
in bookkeeping call to him. Everything that was his parents'\n
life was something he resisted. The boy took a fascination\n
in killing innocent life, the corpses of woodland and plains\n
animals left dying or dead and mutilated as his family traveled\n
the length and breadth of the lands.\n
\n
Beaten. Pain inflicted the first time in his life, listening\n
with angry ears as his father whipped him with his belt time\n
and time again after his victims had been found. The callous\n
disregard Kylriak bore toward the creatures he had murdered\n
sent his father into a rage, and after the pain fell to numbness,\n
Kylriak took the beating without another tear or scream. Nothing\n
seemed to linger for the rest of that night, or for the fortnight\n
after. His mother came to him often, apologizing for her husband's\n
actions, praying that Kylriak would see he did it out of love to\n
help his child return to a path without such sickness. Kylriak\n
pretended to listen, and nurtured his pain in the darkness of his\n
soul.\n
\n
Twelve years Kylriak lived without pain, and then the beating\n
visited him. Two more passed, and he considered him a young man,\n
one with an eye for business. He began to learn his parents' craft,\n
studying as if possessed. He refrained once more from learning the\n
blade, stating he would not tread that path again lest it consume\n
him. Fourteen years of age, hatred fueling his heart and stealing\n
from him his emotions. Lugard was the city they had come to rest for\n
a winter, leaving the world behind for a few months. Lugard was\n
the graveyard his father would inhabit. The Children of the Light,\n
pristine in their white cloaks. Kylriak knew of them, knew of their\n
cold tenets and fanatic devotion to the Creator. One whisper, a few\n
words was all it took for them to seek out his father. The inn\n
was scoured, the patrons herded together as Kylriak's father was\n
singled out. Kylriak lingered with the others, herded by the soldiers.\n
He watched without smile, his visage chained to detatchment as\n
he watched them drag his father away.\n
Flight took him, his mother, and their guards that night. Knowing\n
the Children might come after him, the zealots ignorant that he\n
was the one to offer them their prey, Kylriak convinced his mother\n
to turn the business over to him. They fled, riding hard for Caemlyn.\n
The Children did not follow, having enough to hunt within Lugard.\n
Years fell away, and the caravan became cold. Distant. Business\n
became the drive of life, and Kylriak became even colder, more\n
lethargic in his actions. He spun his webs of trade, minor in all\n
consideration, but enough to raise enough to retire with.\n
\n
Sixteen and he fell sick, a cold taking him. At first his skin prickled,\n
and nausea stole through him. The wisdoms of the various villages\n
and towns they visited knew nothing of what afflicted him. Herbs were\n
given, and some helped to draw him away, to shroud him in a haze of\n
slumber. The sickness passed, and life continued. The nausea returned\n
from time to time, the cold stealing over him whenever his skin\n
prickled. A cold wind always sounded in his ears, whipping around\n
him, gnawing at him. It stole the warmth from him despite that the\n
flames surrounding seemed to burn more fiercely.\n
\n
(He is blocked, and can only channel when a female channeler is present\n
and grasping--or whatever causes
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--

\n`7Date`6:`7 Sun Dec  5 22:39:05 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Josiah
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Seeking Whitecloaks
\n`7CC`6: `7Varulv Dubricus
\n\n
Hey, I'm a return player from some time back and am looking to join WC.  Please mud-mail me if any of this needs correction, editing, etc.\n
\n
Josiah's Desc\n
\n

The man before you seems to have been carved from warped ironwood.  His face is all angles and pits, with a red sheen either from over-exposure to sun or the feverish hatred that burns in his sienna eyes.  His age is hard to determine, for while there is no graying or receding of his close-cropped brown hair, his face is covered in lines from his constant glare and grimace.\n
\n

He is dressed in a faded, green linen shirt and black trousers.  His boots appear to have once been well crafted, but now are overly worn, the leather cracked and scuffed.  At his belt is an unremarkable sword in a similarly cracked leather sheath.\n
There is an air of rigidity and malice radiating from him, and his movement is both stiff and predatory as though his rage is restrained only by a monumental effort of will.\n
\n
Josiah's background\n

Josiah Farelynn is the son of a once wealthy Samaran dye-maker by the name of Duram Farelynn.  His recollections of his mother are old and not a concern to him as his father beat and turned her out early in his childhood over a dalliance with another man.  Duram was a stern man, but raised Josiah to value hard work, fair play, and integrity.  He wept in rage over the torn form of his father when the Dragonsworn swarmed and destroyed Samara.  \n
\n

He returned to the house as soon as the rioting began, fighting his way through filthy, panicked crowds.  Upon arrival, the house was in flames and his father lay dead in the yard, apparently bludgeoned by several men.  A rage followed the last of Josiah's tears and he threw his father's body into the still burning house before returning to the city proper.  His memories of that afternoon are scant and bloody, but he believes he killed blindly and indiscriminately.  He remembers acquiring a sword at some point from a corpse on the street.\n
\n

Several days later, he came to his senses upon awakening in a burned out cellar in Samara, covered in blood and ash.  Aghast at what he feared he had done, he fled east towards Caemlyn, but each day on the road rekindled his rage at the Dragonsworn and the unlawfulness that erupted at the hands of the Dragon Reborn.\n
\n

He is now consumed with guilt overshadowed only by his hatred, but has recently begun talking to Children of the Light.  Their promises of forgiveness, salvation, and justice intrigue him and he is eager to join.\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--

\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Dec  6 03:09:34 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Phaedra
\n`7Subj`6:`7 seeking glee - background

\nThis background is a combination new and old.  Much of the information (such as the trip to the Tower) happened to this character when I played her three+ years ago.  I haven't included any details such as character names or specific actions from that time, because I realize we're in a new timeline, but I was hoping to keep the basics of my experience with this character now, and just add ten years to her life.  If there's anything that needs to change, please let me know.  (Description will come in next email)\n

Phaedra Ashaya was born five and a score years ago in the port town of Aringill.  Her mother was a young commoner named Arrila and her father a young gleeman named Jens.  Jens was by no means near enough the age of retirement to think of it seriously, but when his bride found out they were expecting, he did exactly that, leaving the life of the wandering vagabond behind him.  Having come from a fairly wealthy family, Jens had enough saved to buy a small house and raise his young family in relative comfort.\n

Shortly after the new arrival, Arrila took ill and before the baby could walk, she had died of consumption.  Jens, a young widower with an infant girl, did the only thing his grieving heart would allow: he took up his old profession, hiring a wetnurse to accompany him on his travels as he took his baby girl everywhere he went.\n

Phaedra was from minute one Jens' pride and joy: a living memorium to his lost wife.  He raised her well, dismissing the nanny when the girl was old enough to talk.  Her young life was filled with colors and education in reading, writing, entertainment, culture, and love.  Jens raised her to be a living monument to happiness, vibrance, and hope.\n

Her violet eyes came neither from Jens, whose eyes were crystal blue, or her mother, whose eyes here a light hazel. Jens told her once that her eyes turned violet after her mother passed, because the Wheel spun out the royalty in her blood and infused it in Phaedra's eyes.  Phaedra has no memory of her mother other than the well-crafted stories told by her father, but she carries her mother in her heart.  Around her neck, Phaedra wears a small locket which contains a single strand of her mother's own long yellow hair.\n

When she was 15, Jens brought her to Caemlyn, where he hoped she would be able to strike out on her own in whatever capacity she felt worthwhile.  After a brief stint at the White Tower in the hopes of training there to become Aes Sedai, but finding no talent for the One Power, she returned to Caemlyn.\n

There she decided to follow in her beloved father's footsteps and decided to become a gleeman.  One who could make her mother proud.  She let her already long and shining golden hair grow out to past her waist in remembrance of her mother's own.  She studied with other traveling performers and bards in and around Caemlyn for a little over a year.\n

Her studies were slowed temporarily when she met and older gentleman and began a clendestine relationship with him, only to have it end suddenly with his disappearance.  One day he was with her and lavishing her with gifts, love, and promises, and the next, he was simply gone.\n

Though she despaired for some short time, pessimism is simply not in Phaedra's nature, so she bounced back from that heartache and renewed her studies with vigor.  She left Caemlyn and traveled the world, sometimes with other gleemen or travelers, sometimes alone.  After the end of her first, and only, romantic relationship almost ten years ago, Phaedra left both romance and the thought of becoming a gleeman behind.  She has been traveling and performing, learning arts from whomever would teach her, studying all forms of music and dance, as well as typical street performances like juggling and story-telling.\n
She has met Tinkers, Aiel, Dragonsworn, Whitecloaks, Aes Sedai, Warders, soldiers, blacksmiths, weavers, mayors, and refugees.  Her life has been a rich tapestry of swirling color and sound.\n

But the years are beginning to show now and she wishes to pick up where she left off ten years ago.  The dream to follow in her father's footsteps is rekindled.  The last place she knew to look for him was in Caemlyn, so to Caemlyn she has returned.  Whether she will find him, she knows not, but one thing is sure: she will wear the patched cloak like her father, and her mother's light will shine down on her with pride.\n
\n
Hope that works.  Description to follow.  Thanks!!!\n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Thu Dec  9 14:31:56 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Tarin
\n`7Subj`6:`7 test
\nThe following memories are brought to you by the Letter Q, the number\n
7 and the "Press Justarius to Death with Stones (again)" PR Department.\n
-####, PR Manager for "Pel and Simkin for Cutest Couple" \n
and "Mikki for Best Newbie" and of course, "Justarius for Best IC \n
& OOC Villain"\n
Message 52 : Wed Aug 19 (Justarius)  :: `#Royal `*Decree `@from `#Cairhien`7\n
Citizans,\n
Let it be known that the pretender to the Throne, Dalmear su Riatin,\n
a coward and a letch, has been permently removed from his ill gotten\n
postion of power. No longer with Citizans of Cairhien be under his\n
tyrannical yoke. No longer will people be enslaved for thinking ill\n
of him. The King is dead, after a brave attack on the Sun Court\n
by the stalwart King Justarius Dal'ken Damodred. The fierce battle\n
lasted 3 hours, in which many were slain. In a fit of insanity,\n
Dalmear destroyed both the Sun Crown and the very Sun Throne. You\n
can rest assured that King Justarius will bring back peace to out\n
war torn city, and that prosperity will come again. Long live the\n
King.\n
*A symbol of the Rising Sun*\n
*A symbol of a Tree and Crown*\n
*A symbol of a black, striking serpant*\n
*signed* Teluath Damodred\n
Court scribe and messager\n
Message 53 : Wed Aug 19 (####)      :: *tacked on beneath the `#Royal `*Decree `@from `#Cairhien`7*\n
`7*scrawled onto the paper in relatively neat handwriting*\n
A prayer, a cry for the King!\n
The King is dead\n
long live the king\n
and so we hear from Cairhien\n
we hear grave news from Cairhien\n
and so we hear that yet again\n
their dearest King is dead.\n
We now hear tale of war, war!\n
of civil war,\n
of foul war\n
and so we hear from Cairhien\n
we hear grave news from Cairhien\n
and so we hear that yet again\n
Houses fought o'er throne.\n
And whom did rise to the throne?\n
The man unjust\n
Justarius\n
so do we hear from Cairhien\n
we hear grave news from Cairhien\n
so do we hear that once again\n
Usurper took the throne.\n
And so we hear a hypocrite\n
accuse of one\n
himself has done\n
and so we hear from Cairhien\n
we hear grave news from Cairhien\n
we sadly hear that once again\n
a murd'rer took the throne.\n
But we have hope from pattern here\n
that some may do\n
as he has done\n
that we will hear from Cairhien\n
we'll hear grave news from Cairhien\n
we'll happ'ly hear that once again\n
the murd'rer got his own.\n
`8*unsigned*`7\n
Message 56 : Thu Aug 20 (Justarius)  :: Cairhien update\n
*to all those intersted and keeping an eye on the city*\n
Within the past 3 days, King Justarius has made many issues to his\n
public and to his city, all which seem for the best.\n
He has repelled the high taxation rate on the lower classes, restricting\n
it from the high standers which it had rested so long. He has\n
also compelled the serfs and independent farmers back to the fields\n
under pain of mutiliation and death to provide food for the city\n
for the coming year. It is rumored that they may not have to depend\n
on Tear to get through the next winter.\n
He has also moved the seat of power to his own Damodred estates,\n
while the Sun Court is being rebuilt after the seige done to it.\n
It is unknown if he will rule from the Sun Throne, or from his\n
own private estates.\n
Many new buildings have begun construction since the last hours\n
of the War. Most look like large scale housing projects, intending\n
to hold many people at the same time. As there is no visible flux\n
in the population, there is much speculation as to what the large\n
buildings are for.\n
Mercanaries are on call to the city, as the King is paying well\n
for thier services. The current rate for a man of war is an astonishing\n
5 golden marks a day. The mercanaries are compelled into a 5 year\n
service for such an astounding fee, and are given the option of \n
joining the Royal Guard and to be natrualized if they so wish. It\n
is also unknown why all these warriors are pouring into the city.\n
*the local news/rumor man*\n
Message 57 : Thu Aug 20 (####)      :: *scrawled in the margins around the `#Royal `*Decree `@from `#Cairhien`7\n
`4*written in smooth, flowing script*`7\n
Who shall remember the rise of the sun?\n
Who shall remember the fabled towers, \n
topless in the clouds?\n
Shall we walk the streets of Al'cair'rahienallen?\n
We shall hear laughter no more.\n
Mourn all, for the fall of the flame of the sun,\n
mourn for the Flame, violently extinguished.\n
Who shall remember their great Library?\n
Who shall tell tale of their Feast of the Lights,\n
now the sun has set.\n
Shall we make our way  through the homes of the foregate?\n
We shall hear only their tears.\n
Mourn all, for the sun has set on C

\n`7Date`6:`7 Thu Dec  9 14:33:33 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Tarin
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Test
\nMessage 52 : Wed Aug 19 (Justarius)  :: `#Royal `*Decree `@from `#Cairhien`7\n
Citizans,\n
Let it be known that the pretender to the Throne, Dalmear su Riatin,\n
a coward and a letch, has been permently removed from his ill gotten\n
postion of power. No longer with Citizans of Cairhien be under his\n
tyrannical yoke. No longer will people be enslaved for thinking ill\n
of him. The King is dead, after a brave attack on the Sun Court\n
by the stalwart King Justarius Dal'ken Damodred. The fierce battle\n
lasted 3 hours, in which many were slain. In a fit of insanity,\n
Dalmear destroyed both the Sun Crown and the very Sun Throne. You\n
can rest assured that King Justarius will bring back peace to out\n
war torn city, and that prosperity will come again. Long live the\n
King.\n
*A symbol of the Rising Sun*\n
*A symbol of a Tree and Crown*\n
*A symbol of a black, striking serpant*\n
*signed* Teluath Damodred\n
Court scribe and messager\n
Message 53 : Wed Aug 19 (####)      :: *tacked on beneath the `#Royal `*Decree `@from `#Cairhien`7*\n
`7*scrawled onto the paper in relatively neat handwriting*\n
A prayer, a cry for the King!\n
The King is dead\n
long live the king\n
and so we hear from Cairhien\n
we hear grave news from Cairhien\n
and so we hear that yet again\n
their dearest King is dead.\n
We now hear tale of war, war!\n
of civil war,\n
of foul war\n
and so we hear from Cairhien\n
we hear grave news from Cairhien\n
and so we hear that yet again\n
Houses fought o'er throne.\n
And whom did rise to the throne?\n
The man unjust\n
Justarius\n
so do we hear from Cairhien\n
we hear grave news from Cairhien\n
so do we hear that once again\n
Usurper took the throne.\n
And so we hear a hypocrite\n
accuse of one\n
himself has done\n
and so we hear from Cairhien\n
we hear grave news from Cairhien\n
we sadly hear that once again\n
a murd'rer took the throne.\n
But we have hope from pattern here\n
that some may do\n
as he has done\n
that we will hear from Cairhien\n
we'll hear grave news from Cairhien\n
we'll happ'ly hear that once again\n
the murd'rer got his own.\n
`8*unsigned*`7\n
Message 56 : Thu Aug 20 (Justarius)  :: Cairhien update\n
*to all those intersted and keeping an eye on the city*\n
Within the past 3 days, King Justarius has made many issues to his\n
public and to his city, all which seem for the best.\n
He has repelled the high taxation rate on the lower classes, restricting\n
it from the high standers which it had rested so long. He has\n
also compelled the serfs and independent farmers back to the fields\n
under pain of mutiliation and death to provide food for the city\n
for the coming year. It is rumored that they may not have to depend\n
on Tear to get through the next winter.\n
He has also moved the seat of power to his own Damodred estates,\n
while the Sun Court is being rebuilt after the seige done to it.\n
It is unknown if he will rule from the Sun Throne, or from his\n
own private estates.\n
Many new buildings have begun construction since the last hours\n
of the War. Most look like large scale housing projects, intending\n
to hold many people at the same time. As there is no visible flux\n
in the population, there is much speculation as to what the large\n
buildings are for.\n
Mercanaries are on call to the city, as the King is paying well\n
for thier services. The current rate for a man of war is an astonishing\n
5 golden marks a day. The mercanaries are compelled into a 5 year\n
service for such an astounding fee, and are given the option of \n
joining the Royal Guard and to be natrualized if they so wish. It\n
is also unknown why all these warriors are pouring into the city.\n
*the local news/rumor man*\n

zones to where they should be.\n

\n`7CC`6: `7Varulv Beonca Nicodemus
\n\n
`7I got the list of current zones that I want/don't want to use for the new area revamp.  The\n
areas we keep will have to be incorporated into Nico's large map.\n
\n
Please review and send me any changes.  Once it's 'finalized', I will send this to whomever gets\n
the task of porting everything over to the BP.\n
\n
Please note that most areas that are to be 'ported' do not yet have assigned numbers for the new\n
Revamp (under the heading "BP#), since I don't want to reassign zones until I know what I am\n
keeping.  The few that are assigned are becasue they are already on the BP.\n
\n
Also Note that MP# stands for 'main port' number. Ie: the number of the zone on this port.\n
\n
This list can be viewed at:  `#http://www.geocities.com/vwinters@swbell.net/MITZones12-14-04.htm`7\n
\n
Syrah\n
\n
PS: Items highlighted in blue (except the two noble houses) are guild areas that I'm not sure\n
are being used or not, hence the mails I sent out to Varulv and Beonca asking for used\n
guild zones.\n

`7Doggerel.  Mere tunings.  An old tune, with new words,\n
`7yet one turning up in the oddest of places.  A request\n
`7called for at the occasional inn, when none in White and \n
`7Sunbursts are to be seen.  A tune drifting in with\n
`7refugees and travelers.  \n
`3Four and Twenty Whitecloaks\n
`3sought shadow south of blight\n
`7Copies of the text of a rather irrevrent tune have been \n
`7seen around Caemlyn.  Crumpled balls of parchment at inn tables,\n
`7brazen displays on alley walls, even one actually pinned up \n
`7against a tree in the Oval Plaza, though quickly enough removed.  \n
`3Hauled away the innocents\n
`3Those they did not kill\n
`7No one seems to know who the author is, if indeed the author \n
`7is in Caemlyn, or even who has been spreading the copies \n
`7about.  But the voice can be heard, mocking in its cadence, \n
`7insulting in its words, taunting in its accuracy.\n
`3And all the while to the North\n
`3the Dark One laughed his fill!`7\n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Fri Dec 17 02:20:06 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Dylan
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Dylan for Gleeman!
\nDylan's Desc\n

The man before you is tall and gangly, his limbs seeming too short for his body.  His hair is `#s`3t`#r`3a`#w`7 colored and appears to have never been introduced to a brush or scissors, as it hangs down below his shoulders in a tangled mess.  His eyes are large, `2g`@r`2e`@e`2n`7, and twinkling above an overly bold nose that seems to have been broken a time or two.  In contrast to his hair, a well groomed goatee frames a perpetually smiling mouth.\n
\n

He is dressed in a `*blue`7 linen shirt above simple `3brown`7 trousers.  His boat-like feet are tucked into a pair of soft leather boots that would look more at place on an Aielman.  About the man is a `!p`@a`*t`#c`^h`%w`&`@r`!k`7 cloak, marking him a gleeman.\n
\n
At his hip rides a bulging satchel, travel worn and ink stained from the road.\n
Dylan's BG\n

Born in Ghealdan, Dylan disliked hard work in the extreme as a small boy, but was fascinated with make-believe games.  When he was 19 he ran away to Caemlyn to escape marriage and adult responsibilities.  There he trained with the famed gleeman Jeronymous, and though his fiddle playing skills are only passable, he showed some proficiency with the harp.  He also took quickly to juggling, tumbling, and sleight of hand.  After a year or more of performing about Caemlyn and doing spy work for a young nobleman, Henri Gilthane, he fled the city for the broader world, putting old enmities to his back.\n
\n

He has now returned to Caemlyn after many years of travel, having seen many wonders of the world and even spending some small time in the Aiel Waste.  Though he is slightly nervous about reappearing in his old stomping grounds, the rumors the world over say that Caemlyn is the source of all excitement.  The Dragon Reborn is said to be there frequently, and the Daughter Heir has returned.  Aiel and black-coated male channelers patrol the streets.  No gleeman worth his salt would miss out on that.\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--

\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Dec 27 21:23:16 2004\n`7From`6:`7 Rowen
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Seeking DD
\nRowen's Desc\n
\n

`6Rowen stands five foot eight inches tall.  He has `3s`#a`3n`#d`3y`6 colored, straight hair that he keeps closely cropped.  His eyes are `3h`2a`3z`2e`3l`6 and set slightly deep in his tanned face.  A strong, angular nose protrudes from his face above a short, well-trimmed beard that covers his early wrinkles and strong chin.  He appears to be well-muscled, though not particularly strong or large.\n
\n

`6Rowen stands five foot eight inches tall.  He has `3s`#a`3n`#d`3y`6 colored, straight hair that he keeps closely cropped.  His eyes are `3h`2a`3z`2e`3l`6 and set slightly deep in his tanned face.  A strong, angular nose protrudes from his face above a short, well-trimmed beard that covers his early wrinkles and strong chin.  He appears to be well-muscled, though not particularly strong or large.\n
\n
`7Rowen's BG\n
\n

Rowen Sorenthaine is the second son of Tobias and Aurilla Sorenthaine, both deceased.  His older brother, Daevid, was to inherit the family lands and duties, but took sick shortly before Rowen's parents died, and succumbed to a fever.  So, at age twenty-two, Rowen inherited land and title, though he was ill prepared for it.  His family's estate is in southern Andor nestled by the Cary River near the Hills of Kintara.  Most of the residents grow wheat and raise sheep, but the lush land does allow for small but valuable grape vineyards raised on the estate.\n
\n

More used to riding and overseeing the vineyards and fields, Rowen was unprepared to be thrust into business and politics, but did his best.  The year after his parents' death he traveled to Mayene to seek favorable markets for his grain and wines.  Instead, he found a wife.  He fell deeply in love with Embeth sur Arandaille, youngest daughter of Belial sur Arandaille - one of the Second of Mayene.  Already burdened with three sons, Belial agreed to Rowen's proposal, and the young couple were quickly married.  Rowen used the dowry money to hire artisans to enhance his holdings' irrigation system, and both quantity and quality of grain has risen in the intervening years.\n
\n

Rowen and Embeth are still very much in love, and as an extra bit of good fortune, Embeth is skilled at running the House business.  Though married for over ten years now, the couple remains childless, but it doesn't seem to bother them overmuch.  Rowen spends most of his days handling disputes amongst the commoners and tending his vineyards and horses.  He is a country lord to the marrow, and though he is educated in courtly manners, he prefers to spend his time amongst the commoners that live on his holdings.  The peasants admire him for both his fairness and his good spirit.  He regularly attends local weddings, barn raisings, and funerals.\n
\n

He and Embeth have recently arrived in Caemlyn to celebrate High Chasaline and show their support for the Daughter-Heir.  Like many nobles who spend most of their time away from court, they are both curious and slightly fearful about Morgase' disappearance and the arrival of the Dragon Reborn in their capital.\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--

\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Jan  3 01:01:04 2005\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 WM forms form (hah!)
\n`7CC`6: `7Eradin Beonca
\n\n
Each form can have as many as four tiers, where the skill level\n
is directly equivalent to the WM setting (if there is one) and\n
each 100 is equivalent to the WM lvl.  The breakdown is:\n
\n
Tier 0 has no WM associated with it and is given by skill levels\n
Tier 1 is WM1/1 - WM1/100, and has a skill level of 101-200.\n
Tier 2 is WM2/1 - WM2/100, and has a skill level of 201-300.\n
Tier 3 is WM3/1 - WM3/100, and has a skill level of 301-400.\n
Tier 4 is WM4/1 - WM4/100, and has a skill level of great than\n
\n
I don't think we need to have a separate desc for tier 4 forms.\n
When a form reaches that level, it just uses tier 4 stats with\n
the same text desc.\n
\n
Tier 0 is for totally inept or comical forms - like flailing\n
your arms, shreaking, etc - stuff somebody might realistically do\n
if they'd never held a weapon and were suddenly faced with a well\n
trained foe.\n
\n
Tiers 1 - 4 pertain to WM lvls.\n
\n
Each tier needs different text versions depending on the player's\n
Aggressiveness and follow-through.\n
An attack tier should include:\n
normal initial text\n
aggressive initial text\n
reckless initial text\n
An example might be: Ru'an looses a haphazard horizontal slash\n
from his `3right`7 to `3left`7 aimed at <victim>'s <bodypart>.\n
Whatever orientation you guys use now is fine - with respect to\n
victim or attacker, I don't care.  Also:\n
undefended "practice" hit text\n
undefended "normal" hit text\n
undefended "extreme" hit text\n
This is the end of the form, where it explains what happened if\n
the victim failed to defend.  Like: Ru'an pivots smoothly with\n
left arm extended, raking his weapon across <victim's> <bodypart>\n
with enormous followthrough! Or something.  The next line would be\n
a standard message from the code saying "Ru'an deals Jake a substantial\n
wound" or something similar.\n
There are also form-specific critical failures.  For attacks, they\n
are:\n
fall down text - character fouls up so bad he lands on his arse.\n
stumble/recover text - character botches form but still executes (codely,\n
this lowers the tier by 1 for that turn)\n
loss of weapon text - player looses grip on weapon, total failure\n
to attack\n
counter text - player gives an opportunity for opponent to slip in\n
an attack.  This is a tricky piece of code that simulates IC countering.\n
The players might see "Ru'an raises his sword too high - Jake sees an\n
opportunity to slip in and takes it!" Then it would be Jake's turn. There\n
is another truer system of countering but I wanted both in here.\n
penalty-free text - player loses turn for whatever creative reason you\n
can think of such that he is still ready to go the next turn without\n
being weaponless, etc.\n
\n
Defenses are similar.\n
normal init text\n
aggressive init text\n
reckless init text\n
fall text for cricital failure\n
stumble/recover text\n
loss of weapon text\n
No other critical failures - differs from attacks cuz there's no\n
counter or penalty-free critical failures.\n
Partial "normal" defend text - meaning the defense was fast enough,\n
but not strong enough to stop the attack entirely (i.e. partial - the\n
attack still deals damage - the code actually tracks redirecting weapon\n
directions to new bodyparts for this).\n
Partial "extreme" defend text - attacker is using the 'extreme' setting\n
of followthrough, but the defense was partially successful.\n
Complete "normal" defend text - defense was totally successful.\n
Complete "extreme" defend text.\n
\n
I know - lot of fields.  Most of them will be similar, and I don't\n
think we'll need every form to have every tier defined.  For the\n
basics though, like simple slashes and lunges, it'll have all of these\n
for all tiers.  Incidently, the code structure for an attack form is\n
about 60 fields long, so they have the capacity to hold a lot of\n
different options and affects.\n
\n
-Nic\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Jan  3 01:01:04 2005\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 WM forms form (hah!)
\n`7CC`6: `7Eradin Beonca
\n\n
Each form can have as many as four tiers, where the skill level\n
is directly equivalent to the WM setting (if there is one) and\n
each 100 is equivalent to the WM lvl.  The breakdown is:\n
\n
Tier 0 has no WM associated with it and is given by skill levels\n
Tier 1 is WM1/1 - WM1/100, and has a skill level of 101-200.\n
Tier 2 is WM2/1 - WM2/100, and has a skill level of 201-300.\n
Tier 3 is WM3/1 - WM3/100, and has a skill level of 301-400.\n
Tier 4 is WM4/1 - WM4/100, and has a skill level of great than\n
\n
I don't think we need to have a separate desc for tier 4 forms.\n
When a form reaches that level, it just uses tier 4 stats with\n
the same text desc.\n
\n
Tier 0 is for totally inept or comical forms - like flailing\n
your arms, shreaking, etc - stuff somebody might realistically do\n
if they'd never held a weapon and were suddenly faced with a well\n
trained foe.\n
\n
Tiers 1 - 4 pertain to WM lvls.\n
\n
Each tier needs different text versions depending on the player's\n
Aggressiveness and follow-through.\n
An attack tier should include:\n
normal initial text\n
aggressive initial text\n
reckless initial text\n
An example might be: Ru'an looses a haphazard horizontal slash\n
from his `3right`7 to `3left`7 aimed at <victim>'s <bodypart>.\n
Whatever orientation you guys use now is fine - with respect to\n
victim or attacker, I don't care.  Also:\n
undefended "practice" hit text\n
undefended "normal" hit text\n
undefended "extreme" hit text\n
This is the end of the form, where it explains what happened if\n
the victim failed to defend.  Like: Ru'an pivots smoothly with\n
left arm extended, raking his weapon across <victim's> <bodypart>\n
with enormous followthrough! Or something.  The next line would be\n
a standard message from the code saying "Ru'an deals Jake a substantial\n
wound" or something similar.\n
There are also form-specific critical failures.  For attacks, they\n
are:\n
fall down text - character fouls up so bad he lands on his arse.\n
stumble/recover text - character botches form but still executes (codely,\n
this lowers the tier by 1 for that turn)\n
loss of weapon text - player looses grip on weapon, total failure\n
to attack\n
counter text - player gives an opportunity for opponent to slip in\n
an attack.  This is a tricky piece of code that simulates IC countering.\n
The players might see "Ru'an raises his sword too high - Jake sees an\n
opportunity to slip in and takes it!" Then it would be Jake's turn. There\n
is another truer system of countering but I wanted both in here.\n
penalty-free text - player loses turn for whatever creative reason you\n
can think of such that he is still ready to go the next turn without\n
being weaponless, etc.\n
\n
Defenses are similar.\n
normal init text\n
aggressive init text\n
reckless init text\n
fall text for cricital failure\n
stumble/recover text\n
loss of weapon text\n
No other critical failures - differs from attacks cuz there's no\n
counter or penalty-free critical failures.\n
Partial "normal" defend text - meaning the defense was fast enough,\n
but not strong enough to stop the attack entirely (i.e. partial - the\n
attack still deals damage - the code actually tracks redirecting weapon\n
directions to new bodyparts for this).\n
Partial "extreme" defend text - attacker is using the 'extreme' setting\n
of followthrough, but the defense was partially successful.\n
Complete "normal" defend text - defense was totally successful.\n
Complete "extreme" defend text.\n
\n
I know - lot of fields.  Most of them will be similar, and I don't\n
think we'll need every form to have every tier defined.  For the\n
basics though, like simple slashes and lunges, it'll have all of these\n
for all tiers.  Incidently, the code structure for an attack form is\n
about 60 fields long, so they have the capacity to hold a lot of\n
different options and affects.\n
\n
-Nic\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Tue Jan  4 13:35:44 2005\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 BP note - saving
\nHey, went over this with Nenae and Carissa but here's how to\n
save.  After everybody is done rediting (trying to do this while\n
somebody is can crash the BP, so wait til you're all ready),\n
type 'olc'.\n
\n
This'll bring up a list of zones that need to be saved.  This is\n
separate from the 'save zone internally?' question you answered\n
when quitting redit, btw - you have to do this every so often too,\n
else the next time we reboot/crash everything is lost.\n
\n
From the list that gets brought up with 'olc', it'll say something\n
like '640 needs saving'.  To save zone 640, type 'redit save 640'.\n
I think you can save all zones at once by typing 'OLC save', as well.\n
\n
-Nic\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Tue Jan  4 16:32:52 2005\n`7From`6:`7 Nicodemus
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Mini mod
\nI've got the mud running under mini mode now, but I had to remove zone 51 from\n
all the index files - I'm clueless as to why we can't boot with that zone, but it\n
was causing a seg fault.  51 is the aiel area - i removed it and we rebooted\n
just fine.  I haven't enabled valgrind cuz I don't know what to do with it :p\n
Also, we can still shave more zones off this lift if we have to.\n
\n
-Nic\n

\nHey, I just wanted you to know that I finished the entire Aringill to do list.  The to do list for Caemlyn is done, and I connected all three zones.  The only thing left is to finish the descs in the countryside list.\n
