\nYou were so right about those bottom three zones.  They are ALL a mess.  I\n
am going to do them myself.  Some of the rooms were even linked to other zones!\n
Lots of spelling errors, typos, run-on sentences, bad grammar, and whoever did\n
them, clearly ignored the Ubermap.  Not only that, but the Ubermap is wrong in\n
640.  It totally needs to have farmlands around Caemlyn.  So I am going to add\n
those in.  I still haven't figured out an easy way to update the Ubermap.  I\n
tried to do it in paint, but the fillbucket thingy just doesn't work.  Too many\n
pixels.  Anyway, I just wanted to thank you for pointing it out!  :/ \n
\n
Aya\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Tue Feb  5 00:08:20 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Phaedra
\n`7Subj`6:`7 New Glee background/desc for approval
\nAilsa Collette Chastaine (distant branch of House Delovinde [Talmanes' House])\n
\n
`&Noblesse de lettres\n

`7Once upon a love story, a wealthy but untitled Domani merchant feel madly in love with the beautiful daughter of a Cairhienin Baron.  The young Lady returned her admirer's passion, but her father was a notoriously elitist, power-hungry member of nobility and would never allow his daughter to besmirch the family name by marrying into the peasantry.  In a shrewd move worthy of any of the scheming nobles in their manor houses, the merchant found a long-forgotten country lord who had drunk and gambled his family fortune away and been left destitute.  The lovelorn merchant offered the Lord a healthy sum - enough to set him for the rest of his presumably short life - in exchange for the man's lands and titles.  From the bottom of his barrell, the drunken noble immediately agreed to switch his identity with the merchant and leave Cairhien in perpetuity.\n
\n
`&Gemini\n

`7The plan worked brilliantly and the Baron welcomed Laurent Chastaine of House Delovinde as his new son-in-law.  Laurent and his new bride Evylyn ran away together with the comingled funds of noble houses and the love from romance stories, taking to the road to live an indulgent life as hidden noble merchants.  Adding to their inherited wealth, Laurent continued his merchant trade, and soon the two were rather stupendously rich.  Before two years had passed, Evylyn gave birth to fraternal twins, a boy they named Willem Everett (after his father's 'real' name) and a girl they called Ailsa Collette.  The two were thick as theives, and because of their close relationship, the two parents remained relatively free to continue their love affair.\n
\n
`&White Collar, Black Hat\n

`7Growing up mostly on the road, with their parents largely leaving them to their own devices, Ailsa and Willem learned to take care of each other and themselves even as their personalities began to diverge.  As soon as they were old enough to understand, the twins were told of their heritage, both real and purchased, and instructed in how to comport themselves as nobles.  Precocious and shrewd, Ailsa thought it great fun to live a life of constant trickery and deceit, while Willem took the stance of actually trying to grow into and earn the title his father bought before his birth. \n

`7Though the twins never lost their otherworldly sense of or love for one another, their differing perspectives caused them to begin branching out for alternate ways to experience life.  For Willem, this meant spending more and more time with the sons and daughters of the gentry and aristocracy in every city they visited.  For Ailsa, this meant learning new and ever more crafty ways to be just barely on the wrong side of the law - never for real profit, as she had little need for the money, but mostly for the sheer fun of getting away with things.\n
\n
`&Great Escape\n

`7For their 16th birthday, Ailsa and Willem were to be separated and have individual celebrations befitting their 'noble' stations.  Willem went with his father to the city of Cairhien to be officially presented, and as the elder child to be acknowledged as the heir to the family's titles.  Evylyn took Ailsa to Far Madding, a somewhat remote but important trading center dominated by female sensibilities, to have a proper coming out of sorts.  Though disappointed that they weren't celebrating together, the twins were not so secretly glad that they didn't have to attend the other's party, as neither sounded very enjoyable to the other.\n

`7The cotillion in Far Madding ended up being a huge disappointment to Ailsa, however, as she was expected to be every inch the proper lady, and while she had the bearing and the breeding - at least in part - she was completely bored by the prospect of spending the whole night in a heavy dress parading around with stuffy nobles and their boring boy-children.  While the Ladies of Far Madding bustled around assisting her mother with preparations, Ailsa hatched a scheme of her own, and the first time she was finally left alone, she doffed the frilly dress and scaled out the window in nothing but a tight black bodysuit and her ermine-lined cloak.\n
\n
\n
`&A Friend in the Dark\n

`7Avoiding detection using the skills built up over an adolescence spent, well, avoiding detection, Ailsa found a courtyard wall that could be scaled easily.  Silently scrambling over the stone and into the treed garden on the other side, she came face to face with a young man seated quietly beside a dim lamp, reading.  The boy's pale skin and hair barely showed themselves from under his bucket hat, and as she landed on her cat burglar feet, she crouched down before him, her cloak and hood shrouding her dark skin and hair in inky shadows.  After a few awkward attempts, the two struck up a strangely comfortable conversation which spanned every topic, and before she knew it, the sun was rising.  Having safely thwarted her mother's plans for her birthday, Ailsa gave her strange new friend a kiss on the cheek - her first - and vaulted back over the wall to return to her rooms and face the chewing out she was bound to receive.\n
\n
`&Cloak and Dagger\n

`7Over the next few years, Ailsa and Willem spent less and less time together, though they wrote to one another frequently and their love for one another has never so much as dimmed.  The younger sister divested herself of her parents early, and before the year was out after her misplanned coming out adventure she was effectively on her own.  Having literally bumped into a gleeman on the street corner while out on one of her nighttime prowls of a city - Tear, this time - she divided her time between cat burgling for fun and using her natural physical abilities and charm to develop as a Gleeman herself.  She recently earned her very own patchwork cloak, but she still prefers her shimmering black ermine-lined hooded cloak for most events.\n
\n
`&If you can't be good, be lucky\n

`7While splitting her time training for a respectable (to some) profession and continuing her less-than-lawful practices of breaking and entering with a touch of thievery, Ailsa breaks her years-long streak of never getting caught.  In Ebou Dar one autumn evening, she chooses to lightfoot her way into the manor of a particularly vigilant young noblewoman's library.  The woman, though initially surprised to see a thief boldly enter her home, reacted swiftly and before even Ailsa's reflexes could catch up, the woman's bejeweled marriage knife was at her throat.\n

`7 Luck has always favored this particular cat burglar, though, and she happened to be caught by the one person - probably in all the world - who was on the hunt for a thief to hire.  The Ebou Dari noblewoman offered Ailsa a deal: do a couple specific jobs for her and she would let the girl go on her merry way, with a little profit and a quiet word in the right circles for her trouble.  Ailsa did not need her to spell out the terms of refusal, so she found herself as a thief for hire, doing 'work' rather than having 'fun'.\n
\n
`&Target of Opportunity\n

For a couple years after that chance encounter, Ailsa learned how to get her hands dirty without looking any worse for the wear.  She was, by all public accounts, a rambunctious but harmless noble's daughter who had somehow managed to garner herself acceptance among the Gleemen.  Otherwise, only a select few knew the full extent of her skills.  That list slowly - carefully - grew, and bit by bit she became one of the go-to underbelly lurkers if you needed a little personal espionage or light-fingered thievery done.  She did turn down any job that went beyond petty crime - or at least what she defined as petty crime.  No job requiring physical harm to person or property was accepted.  Exchanging ownership or planting evidence was one thing: directly harming another person was something else entirely, and she didn't take those jobs.  Then one night, while staying in a countryside inn on the road to her family's estates, her twin Willem stepped in out of the rain, looking quite bedraggled and harried.  He told her the former holder of their family's titles has threatened to come forth and expose the fraud for what it is.\n

`7Though she did not particularly care for her own claim to Delovinde, Willem had been struggling for years to make something of himself at court.  To have his parentage questioned thus would at best keep him as a laughingstock at court.  At worst, it could ruin him forever.  Ailsa got all the information about this blackmailer from her brother, gave him her room key, kissed him on the cheek and told him his little sister would take care of it.  For the first time in her legitimate or criminal life, Ailsa took her skills to their ultimate limit.  Slipping unnoticed in the middle of the night into the man's modest accomodations a few towns away, she was in the room for no more than five minutes.  The next morning, a maid came to wake him and instead found him lying in a pool of blood - his blood - never to wake again.\n

`7Willem's legacy secured, Ailsa let the right people know that her banned list had been significantly shortened, though she balances the evil deed with good intentions, and has strict ethical criteria by which she judges a potential target.  Avenging wrongs is her general M.O., and thus far only three other targets have met her requirements.\n
\n
`&Lady and a Tramp\n

`7With the Dragon Reborn running around setting the land afire with chaos and discord, common folk scramble to find some joy and sanity, while nobles scurry to curry favor and assure their positions.  Ailsa is there for them all - to entertain, to delight, to steal, to discredit... Even, should the need arise, to kill.\n
\n
\n
`2Ailsa stands an unremarkable 5'4" tall.  Her trim build is athletic and well-muscled,\n
but her `3w`7id`&e h`7ip`3s`2 and `&am`!p`1l`7e b`1o`!s`&om`2 keep her from truly qualifying as slender or slim.\n
Her heart-shaped face shows her skin is a shade too `7da`3r`7k`2 to qualify as `&f`#a`7i`&r`2, but neither\n
is it `#w`3a`7r`#m`2 enough to indicate a significant time in the `#s`&u`#n`2.\n
\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--

The boy's pale skin and hair barely showed themselves from under his bucket hat, and as she landed on her cat burglar feet, she crouched down before him, her cloak and hood shrouding her dark skin and hair in inky shadows.  After a few awkward attempts, the two struck up a strangely comfortable conversation which spanned every topic, and before she knew it, the sun was rising.  Having safely thwarted her mother's plans for her birthday, Ailsa gave her strange new friend a kiss on the cheek - her first - and vaulted back over the wall to return to her rooms and face the chewing out she was bound to receive.\n
\n
`&Cloak and Dagger\n

`7Over the next few years, Ailsa and Willem spent less and less time together, though they wrote to one another frequently and their love for one another has never so much as dimmed.  The younger sister divested herself of her parents early, and before the year was out after her misplanned coming out adventure she was effectively on her own.  Having literally bumped into a gleeman on the street corner while out on one of her nighttime prowls of a city - Tear, this time - she divided her time between cat burgling for fun and using her natural physical abilities and charm to develop as a Gleeman herself.  She recently earned her very own patchwork cloak, but she still prefers her shimmering black ermine-lined hooded cloak for most events.\n
\n
`&If you can't be good, be lucky\n

`7While splitting her time training for a respectable (to some) profession and continuing her less-than-lawful practices of breaking and entering with a touch of thievery, Ailsa breaks her years-long streak of never getting caught.  In Ebou Dar one autumn evening, she chooses to lightfoot her way into the manor of a particularly vigilant young noblewoman's library.  The woman, though initially surprised to see a thief boldly enter her home, reacted swiftly and before even Ailsa's reflexes could catch up, the woman's bejeweled marriage knife was at her throat.\n

`7 Luck has always favored this particular cat burglar, though, and she happened to be caught by the one person - probably in all the world - who was on the hunt for a thief to hire.  The Ebou Dari noblewoman offered Ailsa a deal: do a couple specific jobs for her and she would let the girl go on her merry way, with a little profit and a quiet word in the right circles for her trouble.  Ailsa did not need her to spell out the terms of refusal, so she found herself as a thief for hire, doing 'work' rather than having 'fun'.\n
\n
`&Target of Opportunity\n

For a couple years after that chance encounter, Ailsa learned how to get her hands dirty without looking any worse for the wear.  She was, by all public accounts, a rambunctious but harmless noble's daughter who had somehow managed to garner herself acceptance among the Gleemen.  Otherwise, only a select few knew the full extent of her skills.  That list slowly - carefully - grew, and bit by bit she became one of the go-to underbelly lurkers if you needed a little personal espionage or light-fingered thievery done.  She did turn down any job that went beyond petty crime - or at least what she defined as petty crime.  No job requiring physical harm to person or property was accepted.  Exchanging ownership or planting evidence was one thing: directly harming another person was something else entirely, and she didn't take those jobs.  Then one night, while staying in a countryside inn on the road to her family's estates, her twin Willem stepped in out of the rain, looking quite bedraggled and harried.  He told her the former holder of their family's titles has threatened to come forth and expose the fraud for what it is.\n

`7Though she did not particularly care for her own claim to Delovinde, Willem had been struggling for years to make something of himself at court.  To have his parentage questioned thus would at best keep him as a laughingstock at court.  At worst, it could ruin him forever.  Ailsa got all the information about this blackmailer from her brother, gave him her room key, kissed him on the cheek and told him his little sister would take care of it.  For the first time in her legitimate or criminal life, Ailsa took her skills to their ultimate limit.  Slipping unnoticed in the middle of the night into the man's modest accomodations a few towns away, she was in the room for no more than five minutes.  The next morning, a maid came to wake him and instead found him lying in a pool of blood - his blood - never to wake again.\n

`7Willem's legacy secured, Ailsa let the right people know that her banned list had been significantly shortened, though she balances the evil deed with good intentions, and has strict ethical criteria by which she judges a potential target.  Avenging wrongs is her general M.O., and thus far only three other targets have met her requirements.\n
\n
`&Lady and a Tramp\n

`7With the Dragon Reborn running around setting the land afire with chaos and discord, common folk scramble to find some joy and sanity, while nobles scurry to curry favor and assure their positions.  Ailsa is there for them all - to entertain, to delight, to steal, to discredit... Even, should the need arise, to kill.\n
\n
\n
`2Ailsa stands an unremarkable 5'4" tall.  Her trim build is athletic and well-muscled,\n
but her `3w`7id`&e h`7ip`3s`2 and `&am`!p`1l`7e b`1o`!s`&om`2 keep her from truly qualifying as slender or slim.\n
Her heart-shaped face shows her skin is a shade too `7da`3r`7k`2 to qualify as `&f`#a`7i`&r`2, but neither\n
is it `#w`3a`7r`#m`2 enough to indicate a significant time in the `#s`&u`#n`2.\n
\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Wed Feb  6 14:24:15 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Mortai
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Mortai Background
\n`7CC`6: `7Maethir Mat
\n\n
Here's Mortai's original background, from when he was joining Heron Company\n
back in the day.  The only thing I think I'll need to change is that rather\n
than winding up in Caemlyn, he met the Band on their way there and joined them\n
just a couple weeks ago.\n
\n
Background as follows:\n
\n

Born in the capital city of Cairhien to a washerwoman and a noble guard, Mortai grew up close enough to the Foregate to feel at home there, but far enough away that he was not inundated by the flood of life there.  As he progressed through childhood, he displayed the typical Cairhienin love for order, and while he was not so much of a solitary child that his parents worried for him, neither was he the type to seek out the attention of crowds.  Rather, he was generally a quiet, focused child, with most of the trouble he got into with his parents resulting from a particular focus being taken too far.\n

Mortai's father's position as a guard meant that he was no stranger to weapons growing up.   His father, though, displayed a typical professional soldier's attitude towards actually fighting, and the few scuffles that he got in to as an adolescent resulted in such a sound thrashing that he developed a similar, but not identical, view on the matter.  He quickly learned to either avoid fights completely, or win them so absolutely that he had no mark by which his father could guess at his activities.\n

Though his father was short, and his mother shorter, even puberty did not do enough to bring Mortai face to face with either.  Though his features turned out beautifully, his body was healthy, nimble, and as sound as anyone could have wished, by his nineteenth birthday he had reached his full adult height of just over five feet tall.\n

When, as parents often do, Mortai's father and mother decided that it was time for him to take a job somewhere and begin to actually earn his living, he started by seeking employment with the same noble that hired his father.  On simple basis of his height and build, he was turned down for that and similar jobs.  Skilled enough for most guard-work though he was, he was simply not suited for any position that hoped to avoid conflict by intimidation.  Though he made a living for a short time working in a tavern waiting tables, he despised the constant bustle of activity and people.  Thus, he almost immediately began seeking employment elsewhere, and was ecstatic when he found a potential employer.\n

The employer in question, a mercenary commander by the name of Sharic, observed that though he was far too lightly built to be much use in any defensive capacity, he was nimble and small enough to be an extremely effective scout and spy, as well as being skilled enough if it came to an actual fight to not be a complete waste of space.  Additionally, for all that he came from a good and loving family, his parents were both practical enough to have no objections to his choice of career, while he had no qualms about taking a position that promised to work for anyone with sufficient coin.  And thus, for the next few years, he was a valued part of that small team, developing some further skill with a weapon, continuing his childhood doctrine of only fighting when victory was certain.\n

Sharic died in a minor scuffle between two lords, and the second in command who stepped up to replace him was one of the front line fighters of the company, a big hearty brawler that Mortai despised on a general level, though not a personal one.  So, politely collecting the pay for the job that ended his employer's life, he bid the company farewell and sought another band to join.\n

Never finding quite as close a fit as the man who first took him in, Mortai moved from company to company, some large, some small, picking up differing skills along the way.  Though his initial training had been with a rapier and halberd, he learned to favor a mix of light weapons and unarmed combat to see him through tricky situations.\n

The turning point in Mortai's life came recently, with the Aiel attacked Cairhien.  Being in a company that had been hired to fight the invaders by a noble lord, he found himself on the wrong end of a numbers game, with allies who's loyalty was backed only by money.  The ensuing combat was the antithesis of his preferred fighting, as he had nowhere to run, no position that was superior he could take, and the overwhelming superiority was on the other side.  Attempting to flee by the rooftops of the same building he was meant to be guarding, he was nearly brought down by an Aiel shortbow, surviving only by flinging himself off the edge.  That same act which saved his life provided him with his first scar, for the wild fling off the rooftop had no time for his usual acrobatic rolling and tumbling.  Or, as proved to be the problem, for watching where he was going.  A projecting beam a story down clipped the side of his head and knocked him unconscious, sparing him the indignity of watching his native city burn.  It was not until some days after he awoke that he learned his father had been killed in the same conflict.\n

It took Mortai some weeks to fully recover from his injury, but with the Aiel occupation of Cairhien and the subsequent lack of good offensive mercenary work, he left what money he could with his mother and took off to find a position elsewhere.  Further, he finally decided that his skill with a weapon was insufficient, his inability to stand up to men averaging a foot or taller than he galling him to the point where he decided also to seek additional training in stand up combat.  Taking off to the north and west, towards the nearest major city of Tar Valon, he found himself in a land already filled with armsmen.  And though the training of a Warder appealed to him, the notion of devoting his life to a prospect he hardly knew did not.  Thus, he stayed in the fabled city of Aes Sedai for no more than a month before turning south, and making his way to Caemlyn.\n
\n
I apologize for formatting, copy paste is an ugly thing.\n
\n
Mortai\n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Fri Feb  8 09:56:50 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Kinje
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Kiziel Navaran
\n     Kiziel Navaran was born to a relatively minor noble house of Far Madding. \n
Though his parents were well enough off that the family never wanted for \n
anything, they were busy enough in maintaining their wealth that he was raised \n
instead by a succession of nannies, tutors, distant family members, and \n
governesses.  None stayed for particularly long, and as a result the child \n
turned largely inward.  His studies fascinated him, and while the world around \n
him changed, books and learned provided constants he was otherwise denied.\n
This inner focus granted him both a blessing, and a curse.  The \n
matriarchal society of Far Madding never had much of an impact on a growing lad \n
who simply couldn't be bothered to look up to see who was telling him to move \n
out of the way, clean his room, or otherwise attempting to break his \n
concentration.  The lack of close supervision from his parents meant no one \n
particularly noticed the trend developing until it was firmly entrenched in his \n
psyche, and by then it was too late.  When Kiziel reached his teens, he was too \n
different for polite Far Madding society, so his family dealt with it the only \n
way they could: they provided for his needs, made sure he was well fed and well \n
supplied with books, and carefully cloistered away from the outside world.\n
He barely noticed.  The exile his parents imposed, something another man \n
might consider torturous, was a boon to him, offering him the chance to devote \n
himself to further studies.  Astronomy was achieved via a telescope he \n
constructed, carefully hand grinding and polishing the glass lenses.  This got \n
him in turn interested in machines which might help automate the process the \n
next time, and he turned his studies to physics and practical mechanics.  From \n
there, his attention soon wandered away from the automated lens polishing and \n
grinding that started it, and soon the little workstation his family had \n
provided adjacent to his room was littered with prototypes and half-finished \n
machines.  The metals he had available were, however, insufficient to the tasks \n
he had in mind, lacking sufficient tensile strength to hold the precise forms \n
he required in the sizes he needed, and so again his attention shifted.  This \n
time, alchemy and metallurgy held his interest for quite some time, as he \n
devoted himself to the study of chemical reactions, purifying and refining \n
metals before remixing them.  His lab was not sufficient in size to allow him \n
full freedom to experiment - it's difficult to construct a blast furnace in a \n
20x20 room, after all - but he did what he could, and his results were \n
sufficient for his purposes at the time.\n
His studies continued uninterrupted, the young man meeting few enough \n
servants and no one from outside the household, until sometime shortly after an \n
18th birthday he somehow missed.  Taking his latest book with him out into the \n
gardens to read, donning a hat to shelter his skin from the harsh sun, he found \n
himself leaning against a tree and reading until after dark.  It was then that \n
the strange girl, clad all in black, clambered over the wall and dropped down \n
practically on top of him.  Though vague thoughts of assassination danced \n
briefly through his mind, Kiziel was hardly afraid - if anything, he was \n
intensely curious at this sudden intrusion into his secluded world.  Young - \n
younger than he - and with skin dark enough to notice even in the dim light of \n
the single lantern he had been using to read, she presented a sudden and \n
startling reminder of the outside world.  Greeting her, the young man \n
hesitantly attempted to converse with her about the metallurgic tome he was \n
currently reading.  That fell flat, but she countered with questions of her \n
own, and in time the two were conversing on a broad variety of topics, spurring \n
an interest in outside discourse Kiziel had never truly known.  Further, while \n
the girl was clearly well educated - and thus probably noble - she demanded no \n
more deference than he, allowing for comfortable discourse to proceed \n
naturally.  When dawn rose, she delivered a peck to his cheek, and then fled \n
over the same wall over which she came in. \n
Kiziel made up his mind.  The previous dawn, his bedroom, small but \n
overfilled library and tiny workshop had been enough.  By the following \n
evening, everything was too small, too cramped, and too limited.  He knew his \n
parents wouldn't ever let him leave with their blessing - the chance that he \n
would bring shame on his family was too high, and even he had figured out what \n
they were doing by now - so instead he began planning in private.  Over the \n
next couple years, he carefully gathered supplies, using his studies as a guise \n
now while he put together some easily transported valuables.  Then, when he \n
felt he had enough, he packed his few changes of clothes and left, pack on his \n
back, escaping over the same wall his strange friend had used to come in.\n
From there, he wandered for a time.  He knew he couldn't stay in the city, \n
so, recalling the girl making some mentions of Cairhien, he found himself on \n
the road headed north, his family's name getting him past the gate guards.  He \n
had traded for some supplies - foodstuffs that would keep for weeks, a bedroll, \n
and some sturdier clothes, but had no horse, no weapons, and no practical \n
experience with the outside world.\n
His progress was slow, as he found himself stopping frequently to trade \n
his dwindling supplies of metals for supplies, asking for directions, never \n
quite managing to learn decent horsemanship despite purchasing a placid mare to \n
help him in his quest. \n
It took him a further year, but he made it nearly halfway to the city of \n
the Hill of the Golden Dawn before being mugged just south of Caemlyn, left \n
with the clothes on his back and little more.\n
In Caemlyn, Kiziel traded his knowledge for food.  Specifically, he found \n
small bits of work at apothecaries, smithies, and factories, using knowledge \n
and hands which were as skilled as a trained craftsman to feed himself and \n
eventually find a small room.  Still, he was not particularly successful in \n
saving up enough to move on towards his goal - his lack of practical, worldly \n
knowledge meant that he had trouble managing what coin he made, and he often \n
suffered for a lack of practice in bargaining.\n
Finally, contemplating simply giving up his quest, Kiziel was offered a \n
strange opportunity.  A band of men dressed in strange black coats, all \n
wielding swords were offering a chance for any men who would take it: Be \n
tested, and if able, join the most elite army of the Dragon Reborn.  The army \n
part did not particularly interest the Far Madding wanderer, but the \n
opportunity to talk to a channeler that, he could not pass up.  Lining up with \n
several others, he found his questions run over roughshod, not getting the \n
chance to ask any of the academic questions he had in mind, instead being sat \n
down and told to stare at a flame hovering in the air before him.\n
This part, at least, was easy.  Kiziel had never seen a man channel before \n
- had never even met anyone who had claimed to meet a channeler, so the strange \n
phenomenon before him captured his attention immediately.  In less than a \n
minute, the older black coated man had clapped him on the shoulder and welcomed \n
him to the Dragon's forces.\n
Here, he excelled.  While there were hardships, of course, a man \n
accustomed to forgetting his meal until it was stone cold on a workbench nearby \n
had few objections to eating his meal cold, and someone who had passed out \n
leaning against a tree with a book in his lap dozens of times found sleeping on \n
the cold earth faintly comforting, somehow.  \n
Rather, it was the discipline that Kiziel lacked, the sense of army \n
structure.  The One Power came to him naturally - while he would never have \n
channeled without training, his strength was immediately apparent, and the \n
esoteric study of advanced weaves was to him simply an extension of the \n
academia he adored.  Indeed, some of the metallurgy that had always escaped him \n
was soon within his reach - by the time the Lord Dragon arrived to create ranks \n
on the Farm, he needed no blast furnace to forge quality steel, heating and \n
compressing it easily with Saidin.  His ability to follow orders was spotty, \n
at times, but provided the task given to him was simple enough, he would pursue \n
it with the dedication of a man devoted to making anything keeping him from his \n
studies go away.\n
He found himself a Dedicated almost from the offset, simply due to raw \n
undeniable strength, but it was after the Lord Dragon observed him in a spar he \n
had been goaded into by one of Taim's Asha'man that he was awarded his second \n
pin.  This granted him a measure of authority he had never asked for, but also \n
a measure of autonomy he had been seeking for quite some time.  Finally, nearly \n
seven months after joining the Asha'man, almost three years after fleeing Far \n
Madding, and twenty-five years after his birth, he had the chance to travel the \n
world looking for resources, finding books he had never known existed, and \n
meeting people who might, potentially, share his interests.  True, he was asked \n
occasionally to use his power for some specific task or another, being sent off \n
on recruiting runs since his ability to form Gates was steady and consistent, \n
but this was a fair trade for sometimes having captive audiences whose ears he \n
could talk off on one topic or another.  More than one Recruit was forced to \n
endure a lesson in channeling Earth that devolved into an in depth explanation \n
of metal alloys, or a lesson in Fire that ended up discussing how heat \n
resistant various materials were.\n
It was perhaps a month ago that the new Asha'man found himself being \n
shunted off the Black Tower grounds by a group of Taim's men who had grown \n
tired of his prattling.  They did not kick him out completely, of course - he \n
was too valuable for that - but instead he found himself in a semi-permanent \n
posting in Caemlyn, operating a shop that acted as a secondary base for \n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Fri Feb  8 09:56:50 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Kinje
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Kiziel Navaran
\n     Kiziel Navaran was born to a relatively minor noble house of Far Madding. \n
Though his parents were well enough off that the family never wanted for \n
anything, they were busy enough in maintaining their wealth that he was raised \n
instead by a succession of nannies, tutors, distant family members, and \n
governesses.  None stayed for particularly long, and as a result the child \n
turned largely inward.  His studies fascinated him, and while the world around \n
him changed, books and learned provided constants he was otherwise denied.\n
This inner focus granted him both a blessing, and a curse.  The \n
matriarchal society of Far Madding never had much of an impact on a growing lad \n
who simply couldn't be bothered to look up to see who was telling him to move \n
out of the way, clean his room, or otherwise attempting to break his \n
concentration.  The lack of close supervision from his parents meant no one \n
particularly noticed the trend developing until it was firmly entrenched in his \n
psyche, and by then it was too late.  When Kiziel reached his teens, he was too \n
different for polite Far Madding society, so his family dealt with it the only \n
way they could: they provided for his needs, made sure he was well fed and well \n
supplied with books, and carefully cloistered away from the outside world.\n
He barely noticed.  The exile his parents imposed, something another man \n
might consider torturous, was a boon to him, offering him the chance to devote \n
himself to further studies.  Astronomy was achieved via a telescope he \n
constructed, carefully hand grinding and polishing the glass lenses.  This got \n
him in turn interested in machines which might help automate the process the \n
next time, and he turned his studies to physics and practical mechanics.  From \n
there, his attention soon wandered away from the automated lens polishing and \n
grinding that started it, and soon the little workstation his family had \n
provided adjacent to his room was littered with prototypes and half-finished \n
machines.  The metals he had available were, however, insufficient to the tasks \n
he had in mind, lacking sufficient tensile strength to hold the precise forms \n
he required in the sizes he needed, and so again his attention shifted.  This \n
time, alchemy and metallurgy held his interest for quite some time, as he \n
devoted himself to the study of chemical reactions, purifying and refining \n
metals before remixing them.  His lab was not sufficient in size to allow him \n
full freedom to experiment - it's difficult to construct a blast furnace in a \n
20x20 room, after all - but he did what he could, and his results were \n
sufficient for his purposes at the time.\n

:D\n
\n
Aya \n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Sun Feb 10 00:05:03 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Ayasha
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Guild Tower
\nRissa and I would like to bring back the concept of the Guild Tower, so that\n
players can have easy access to their guild areas, and those guilds that don't\n
have guild areas will have a place to link one to eventually, and to recall to\n
in Caemlyn.  \n
\n
I'd need to create a new zone for this.  I don't want to use the Player\n
Testings, since those are for the Ubermap it seems.  But, I am apparently not\n
godly enough to make a new zone.  So, was wondering if you could grant me that\n
power, or if you can make one for us?  \n
\n
Thanks.  :)\n
\n
Aya \n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Feb 11 15:58:57 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Heathe
\n`7Subj`6:`7 BG for Heathe Maerran

\nHeathe was born in Arafel, summer and winter on the farm, spring and fall in the city of Fal Moran with various relatives.  At the age of two, fourteen summers to the southern folk, his parents, he and his brother and two sisters leave their farm to settle in Far Madding.  There is no longer a farm, only the city and beyond it the grassy plains and gently rolling countryside with its winding rivers.  The reasons for their relocation can only be guessed by the children, and for three years, they make the transition from borderland to southern civilization, and from youth to young adult.\n

Far Madding is nowhere he wants to be at seventeen, Heathe is excited by the thought of seeing the world, maybe as far away as Tar Valon, or even Arafel, though he ends up traveling north and west, misjudging his coin and stalling in Whitebridge, stuck there for months after several more attempts to gain employ eastward.  From helpful souls in Whitebridge he learns that there is always work in Baerlon and, tempted by the wages mentioned, he reverses direction and once more goes west.  At nineteen years of age, he stands behind a cart filled with iron ore, his canvas smock saturated with fine black powder:  iron dust intermingled with rock powder from the adjacent quarry.\n

It is hard work, but the pay is more than what he expected from the gossip in Whitebridge.  He assumed then that the wages were an exaggeration, but it was about right, and he is able save some for another attempt at migration east.  The world is changing in leaps and bounds to hear the news, though the news itself comes in as fast as it ever did --not very-- and just as accurately, also not very.  He tries to filter through it and act as though most of it has to be untrue, though Light blast him for a gullible fool, he does believe it.  Traveling east becomes more and less appealing.  He continues to save his coin, shares a room with a friend, then with several friends.  Restlessness makes him miserly one minute, to save enough to leave earlier, and careless the next, wasting coin because of intolerable boredom.  He passes up several opportunities to work his way east as a guard or servant.  He looks the part but isnt qualified with his minimal weapons training, and he hasnt been able to picture himself polishing boots, scraping pots and doing laundry.  It doesnt take him long to decide he isnt going to pretend to know skills he doesnt have.\n

His friends, the few he keeps, soak up his extra coin one evening that turns into early morning, and he wakes up in an upstairs room at an inn, aching in several places with no idea why and missing a few things.  His boots, the boots he needs to work in the mines, are gone.  He paid good coin for those.  His head is splitting open agony, and his mouth is dry, gritty and tastes bad.  The corner of one side of his mouth twinges, and there is an immediate coppery trickle to explore gingerly with rough fingers.\n

He discovers he is on the other side of town than his rented space, and it is a long walk back on streets that are basically channels of churned up mud, almost always crowded with men and beasts.  He loses his footing several times to avoid hooves nearly the size of his head stepping too close to his unprotected feet.  Oxen and draft horses both haul wagons piled with bars of steel and lesser metals, the beasts barely straining, thick muscles shaking under healthy hides as they plod steadily forward.\n

The rest of his belongings he sees before he enters the front door of his house.  They are scattered across the ground, half in the grassy plot next to the steps and half in the mud of a narrow side street, which is cobbled high but muddied many times over by tracks off of the main streets.\n

He feels too sick to be angry, and his cursing is half-hearted.  He opens the door to go into the house and begins to ask what--? when his friends fist meets his face, knocking him back to stumble down the stairs and wobble another step further from the house, only to slip in the mud and land solidly on his back.  Very painful.  Not going to do that again.  He rolls to his side and blinks back tears.  Light burn them, is his first thought, and then since he is not a completely unreasonable young man, he thinks, what did I do? He hauls himself back on his feet and stares down at the few things he can claim.  A month of work would pay for new, but he needs boots now, for work this afternoon.  Burn them.  Burn me.  He walks out into the mud again and procures coin he has placed in a moneylenders keeping.  He buys boots.  He goes to work, and he tries again to save, full of self pity and too weak for a full tenday to try and salvage friendships.\n

He gives the rumors and gossip a much closer consideration.  To fight for a cause.  He is breaking his back and his will mindlessly fighting with a heap of ore anyone could push or pull.  Of course he is good at his work.  Anyone with a strong back could do it.  He wants to be more than that before he is graying, an ironic thought if an honest one.  Anyone looking close could tell him his dark wheaten hair is already more than half grayed despite his age.\n
--He is signed in, tested for ability, carted to the Black Tower and trained to Soldier with an affinity for healing.--\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Mon Feb 11 15:58:57 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Heathe

At the age of two, fourteen summers to the southern folk, his parents, he and his brother and two sisters leave their farm to settle in Far Madding.  There is no longer a farm, only the city and beyond it the grassy plains and gently rolling countryside with its winding rivers.  The reasons for their relocation can only be guessed by the children, and for three years, they make the transition from borderland to southern civilization, and from youth to young adult.\n

Far Madding is nowhere he wants to be at seventeen, Heathe is excited by the thought of seeing the world, maybe as far away as Tar Valon, or even Arafel, though he ends up traveling north and west, misjudging his coin and stalling in Whitebridge, stuck there for months after several more attempts to gain employ eastward.  From helpful souls in Whitebridge he learns that there is always work in Baerlon and, tempted by the wages mentioned, he reverses direction and once more goes west.  At nineteen years of age, he stands behind a cart filled with iron ore, his canvas smock saturated with fine black powder:  iron dust intermingled with rock powder from the adjacent quarry.\n

It is hard work, but the pay is more than what he expected from the gossip in Whitebridge.  He assumed then that the wages were an exaggeration, but it was about right, and he is able save some for another attempt at migration east.  The world is changing in leaps and bounds to hear the news, though the news itself comes in as fast as it ever did --not very-- and just as accurately, also not very.  He tries to filter through it and act as though most of it has to be untrue, though Light blast him for a gullible fool, he does believe it.  Traveling east becomes more and less appealing.  He continues to save his coin, shares a room with a friend, then with several friends.  Restlessness makes him miserly one minute, to save enough to leave earlier, and careless the next, wasting coin because of intolerable boredom.  He passes up several opportunities to work his way east as a guard or servant.  He looks the part but isnt qualified with his minimal weapons training, and he hasnt been able to picture himself polishing boots, scraping pots and doing laundry.  It doesnt take him long to decide he isnt going to pretend to know skills he doesnt have.\n

His friends, the few he keeps, soak up his extra coin one evening that turns into early morning, and he wakes up in an upstairs room at an inn, aching in several places with no idea why and missing a few things.  His boots, the boots he needs to work in the mines, are gone.  He paid good coin for those.  His head is splitting open agony, and his mouth is dry, gritty and tastes bad.  The corner of one side of his mouth twinges, and there is an immediate coppery trickle to explore gingerly with rough fingers.\n

He discovers he is on the other side of town than his rented space, and it is a long walk back on streets that are basically channels of churned up mud, almost always crowded with men and beasts.  He loses his footing several times to avoid hooves nearly the size of his head stepping too close to his unprotected feet.  Oxen and draft horses both haul wagons piled with bars of steel and lesser metals, the beasts barely straining, thick muscles shaking under healthy hides as they plod steadily forward.\n

The rest of his belongings he sees before he enters the front door of his house.  They are scattered across the ground, half in the grassy plot next to the steps and half in the mud of a narrow side street, which is cobbled high but muddied many times over by tracks off of the main streets.\n

He feels too sick to be angry, and his cursing is half-hearted.  He opens the door to go into the house and begins to ask what--? when his friends fist meets his face, knocking him back to stumble down the stairs and wobble another step further from the house, only to slip in the mud and land solidly on his back.  Very painful.  Not going to do that again.  He rolls to his side and blinks back tears.  Light burn them, is his first thought, and then since he is not a completely unreasonable young man, he thinks, what did I do? He hauls himself back on his feet and stares down at the few things he can claim.  A month of work would pay for new, but he needs boots now, for work this afternoon.  Burn them.  Burn me.  He walks out into the mud again and procures coin he has placed in a moneylenders keeping.  He buys boots.  He goes to work, and he tries again to save, full of self pity and too weak for a full tenday to try and salvage friendships.\n

He gives the rumors and gossip a much closer consideration.  To fight for a cause.  He is breaking his back and his will mindlessly fighting with a heap of ore anyone could push or pull.  Of course he is good at his work.  Anyone with a strong back could do it.  He wants to be more than that before he is graying, an ironic thought if an honest one.  Anyone looking close could tell him his dark wheaten hair is already more than half grayed despite his age.\n
--He is signed in, tested for ability, carted to the Black Tower and trained to Soldier with an affinity for healing.--\n

\n`7Subj`6:`7 Tiernan Laoranth - Eli's rename

\nGrowing up rich can really be a much bigger burden than most people understand, even in the Borderlands.  For the youngest son of the best and most successful banker in Chachin and the best and most sought after horse trainer in Kandor, this was certainly the case.  Tiernan was the sixth and final child born to two very wealthy, very influential, very busy, and very wealthy people.  Because of their net worth, and the time it takes to build and maintain that level of wealth without being a member of the nobility, the boy's parents basically passed him off to his older brothers and sisters, along with a steady stream of nursemaids and governesses.\n
\n

As it was, they were blessed with a boy who got along with everyone - he always had a cheerful demeanor and never shied away from a conversation or a new friend or a point if interest.  There was something of a curse to that blessing, because he was also undaunted and unflappable - he never shied away from a back alley card game or a practical joke or a drink with the boys.  His tutors complained regularly that he never took anything seriously, but he also never failed any test they put to him to gauge his abilities.  A charmer from the start, he could even make his sisters blush and giggle like courting girls - and he by no means stopped his practice with his sisters.  More than once Tiernan has been publicly repudiated for his quite ungentlemanly behavior with the young daughters of Chachin, but not even the threats and the yelling and the weeping women he left in his wake were enough to dissuade him from trying it again with the next pretty young thing to catch his transitory interest.\n
\n

His demeanor being totally unsuited for either banking or equestrian training, the boy's parents continued their policy of "ignore him and he'll go away", but because they took at least some responsibility for his well-being, they continued providing him with an allowance which kept him in drink, cards, books, women, and general fun - and which also served to prolong his adolescence and prevent him from learning about how the real world works.\n
\n

Which is why, when on vacation with a few of his closest friends, hunting far from home in the vast forests and plains north of Andor, the group of young, mostly spoiled minor nobles and other man-children decided to go to Caemlyn - on a whim.  They had a rousingly successful fortnight in the uptight capital of the large, wealthy central nation.  One night while they were out (still) drinking, a small group of black-coated men were quietly but openly accepting/requesting applicants to go join the Dragon Reborn's army of male channelers - the Asha'man.\n
\n

Drunk, and foolish, Tiernan and three of his closest - and drunkest - friends dared each other to take the mens' test for a lark.  Tiernan went last, and was bolstered by the failures of his buddies, each one receiving more and more good-natured jeers as they were told they would not be eligible.  Expecting the worst treatment of the lot, the Kandori banker's son sobers up almost immediately upon being informed that in fact he was exactly the type of man they were looking for.  Despite his protests, which somehow even he felt sounded hollow, the Asha'man insisted the results were indisputable.  Rather than the jeers and laughter he expected to hear from his friends, he heard nothing at all, and when he turned around they were gone.\n
\n

Abandoned by his fairweather friends, Tiernan accepted his fate - to go mad and die - as good-naturedly as he could, and journeyed with the recruiting team through their magical portal into another place.  Despite the harsh treatment (no hot food or comfortable beds? no women?), the Kandori lad treated the whole thing with the same lightheartedneess and devil-may-care attitude with which he approached everything else.  Well, that behavior doesn't go over well in the Asha'man, and it wasn't long before a sense of discipline and purpose came to make up for its lifelong absence.  After a couple close calls and brushes with certain death caused by his flippant approach, Tiernan wised up and actually started applying himself for the first time to something more important and real than chasing skirts or winning at cards.\n
\n

He discovered a real aptitude for Fire and Spirit, two elements that he found spoke to him deeply.  One thing he always found it hard to do was fight.  Not that he was a pacifist, and he did win many of the practice combats he got into at the Black Tower, but he was a lover, not a fighter, and though he learned to do it - and relatively well all things considered - he never really learned to like it.  Tiernan is a people-person: his charm and good graces made him a natural fit for Rahien.  He alone has managed to attract more recruits than any three others in his Talon.  (OOC Note: negotiable, obviously, more a point on his charisma than anything.)\n
\n

One fairly recent event altered the way he felt about combat, however.  He was chosen - along with almost every other available Blackcoat - to accompany the Lord Dragon to defend Illian from the invading Seanchan army.  His skill with Fire and Spirit seemed to come in very handy there, and he discovered that fighting alongside his brothers in arms against a true and present threat in the name of the Dragon Reborn and the Light...  Well *that* was marvelous.\n
\n

Having learned to channel when the Dark One's foul oilslick still coated the whitewater purity of Saidin, Tiernan was overjoyed that the Dragon Reborn had actually managed to rid the Power of its madness-and-rot-inducing Taint.  For days he just walked around dipping his will into the river of life - just the tip, just to see what it felt like.\n
\n

Now well into his time as a Dedicated, Tiernan is looking to take the next step.  He is coming into his own and learning how to balance the joy and exuberance of youth with the dedication and purpose of a real life.  He has his sights set on becoming a full Asha'man, and on being able to show his family that he wasn't a waste after all, and that he can really matter in the world.\n
\n
\n
Tiernan description:\n
\n
\n

Standing just a hair taller than an average adult male, Tiernan neither towers over nor shrinks under most people.  His chocolate brown hair is kept short, but is very curly, and as the curls move they reveal lighter brown and blond highlights.  Tanned skin shows sun exposure was a leisurely activity for him rather than an issue of occupation or poverty.  The cut of his face is thin and long, his chin and nose both seemingly sliced to rounded points, and even his large green eyes come to angular points on the ends.  Though he appears to be no more than perhaps 20 or 22 summers old, the man has laughlines around the corners of his lips and eyes to fit a much older man.  Possibly that's because it is rare indeed to see Tiernan without a wide smile on his face or a twinkle in his eyes.\n
\n

It would be tricky to determine this man's country of origin based on his clothes.  He is garbed head to toe in fine cloth, all of the same deep black dye, cut in the style of the now-famous uniform of the Dragon Reborn's army of male channelers, the Asha'man.  The high collar on the well-tailored jacket displays a polished, gleaming pin of a stylized sword, marking him out - to those who know what to look for - as a Dedicated.  At his left hip is a slightly curving sword in its own raven-colored sheathe with simple but fine silver detailing.\n
\n

shelves \n

warder \n

easle \n

and it's current showpiece, the `3f`2e`@r`2n`7.\n

couple \n

short `8d`3a`8rk hair`7, broad shoulders and `8d`4a`8rk eyes`7.  He is dressed in\n
`8dark colors`7 with l`&a`7ce at the cuff and neck.  The woman has `3a`1ub`3u`1r`3n`7 hair\n
and `2green eyes`7 with slender frame.  She is wearing a modest `2green dress`7\n
with l`&a`7ce at the neck and cuff.  They both appear to be in their mid-\n
twenties.  The background is faded and somewhat indistinguishable for\n
the painting itself has faded and turned `3y`7e`3ll`7o`3w`7 with age.... more than\n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Thu Feb 14 19:15:49 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Jezz
\n`7Subj`6:`7 my room
\nThe Chambers of Jezz Sedai \n
The large northern window is draped delicately in a thin veil of\n
w`&hit`7e `&M`7u`&r`7a`&nd`7ia`&n`7 l`&a`7ce which is coupled with heavy, `8black`7 c`&r`8ush`&e`7d v`8e`7l`8vet`7\n
curtains.  The v`8e`7lv`8e`7t`8ee`7n curtains are drawn back and held in place by\n
a l`&a`7cey w`&hit`7e ribbon.  The view from the window is one to behold for it\n
shows the vast North Harbor but the Dragonmount just to the west of the\n
Tower as well.  Before the window, sitting on a dainty pedestal is a\n
small potted `3f`2e`@r`2n`7, it's `@l`2ea`@f`2y `3v`2i`3n`@e`2s`7 reaching ever onward towards the\n
floor.  Beside the window, as if company to the `3f`2e`@r`2n`7, stands an `3easle`7.\n
A `&l`!a`1c`3q`7u`3e`1r`!e`&d `3m`1a`!p`1l`3e`8-`3w`1oo`3d`7 desk sits squarely in the middle of the eastern\n
wall.  High `3shelves`7, at least eight high, line the walls on either side\n
of the desk.  A `3painting`7 hangs above the desk silently.  Positioned\n
against the western wall is a canopy bed of `&l`!a`1c`3q`7u`3e`1r`!e`&d `3m`1a`!p`1l`3e`7.  The bed\n
is hidden by a m`&i`7st of d`&ia`7ph`&i`7n`&ou`7s w`&hit`7e cloth.  The m`&i`7st is parted on\n
one side by a l`&a`7cey `8black`7 r`8i`7bbon giving a peek to the delicate pillows\n
and w`&hit`7e l`&a`7ce`8-`7overl`&a`7id comforter set.  On the southern wall, near the\n
door, stands an `3armoire`7.  Beside the armoire sits a vanity with a large\n
m`&i`7rr`&o`7r.  A `8s`7i`&lv`7e`8r`7 handled comb and brush set `8g`7l`&i`^s`&t`7e`8n`7 silently beside a\n
dainty `&j`7e`8w`7e`&l`7r`8y`7 box.  Hanging on either side of the vanity mirror are\n
two paintings, one of a `3couple`7 and the other of her `3Warder`7.\n
\n
shelves \n
Lining each of the `3shelves`7, sixteen in total, are a myriad of `6books`7.\n
The subjects of the `6books`7 vary from `8politics`7 and `4laws`7 of different\n
nations, to `^Prophecies`7.  There are `6books`7 on `#Healing`7 and other uses of\n
the `5Power`7 as well as a few on `2war`7 and `1Artur Hawking`7.  Even a few `6books`7\n
for recreational reading.  Each subject is arranged into it's own section,\n
giving order to what could have been a very chaotic place.\n
\n
armoire \n
Standing near to six feet in height is this `&l`!a`1c`3q`7u`3e`1r`!e`&d `3m`1a`!p`1l`3e`8-`3w`1oo`3d`7\n
`3armoire`7.  Holding within it's protective depths, should one explore\n
within, are dresses and gowns in all shades of `2g`@r`2e`7e`2n`7 and `4b`*l`^u`6e`7.  W`&hit`7e\n
l`&a`7cey scarves hang upon pegs just inside the door.  Soft boots and\n
slippers line the bottom, giving an array of complete ensembles for\n
any and all occasions.\n
\n
warder \n
Relaxing easily in comfortable, forest-green upholstered chair, the\n
broad shouldered Kandori man in question has a languid presence of a\n
lounging wolf.  `3B`1r`3on`1z`3e`7 and `3e`2ar`3th`2e`3n`7 tinged eyes look out from behind an\n
angular, ruggedly handsome face.  His unfettered, straight `#d`3u`#ne`7 blonde\n
lengths fall past is shoulders with an intricate braid over his right\n
ear.  His chest is covered with a fine w`&hit`7e linen tunic which is\n
unlaced at the neck.  The tunic is paired with an overlapping `8black\n
vest`7.  A pair of `8dark`7, form-fitting breeches reach into a pair of `8hard\n
leather boots`7 which are turned down at the ankle.  Propped against the\n
arm of the chair are two scabbards, one shorter than the other.  In his\n

\n`7Date`6:`7 Tue Feb 19 09:11:03 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Rissa
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Immly issues
\n`7CC`6: `7Anazail Jaiden Duren Ayasha
\n\n
Couple things I'd like to put on the table to be solved over the next little while as we work to bring code back and get everything in line:\n
\n
`!1) `1Code vs RP exp.`7\n
\n
When code comes back in and exp can be awarded for killing mobs, how will that exp be awarded vs how RP exp will be awarded?\n
\n

On our drive back from Austin, the three of us talked about several different options, including bringing back the separation of code and RP levels.  The main crux was that code levels could be balanced to effectively eliminate the arbitrary assignment of 100 OCS, giving us the ability to make flowstrengths a scale of 1-100 (rather than a 'high' flowstrength being around 40 like right now).  Whether or not exp is all one system for code and RP or if they're split between code and RP levels, the question remains of how to balance RP exp gain with code exp gain, both overall (i.e., does RP award 100exp per emote and code awards 10exp per mob) and as a composite (i.e., how much RP exp = how much code exp *per emote*).\n
\n

Anazail could explain it better because he has a better grasp on the math and a better idea how to balance code and RP exps, but while I really don't personally like the concept of code levels, they made some very persuasive arguments for the reintroduction of that system.\n
\n
`!2) `1Channeling combat.`7\n
\n

I would like to see a system of channeling combat that is less like D&D spells and more like channeling.  Anazail and I have discussed several options - and I think Anazail and Duren have talked about it a little bit, too - and while I know physical combat and the code combat system (along with econ, etc.) are the priorities, eventually I would like to bring channeling combat up to snuff with the rest of it.\n
\n
Included here is the necessity of balancing chan/non-chan combat, including the requirement that the ambush be respected by the code.\n
\n
`!3) `1Multiguilds and Guildskills.`7\n
\n

Last week, Zach and I had a discussion regarding the multiguild system we have right now.  He pointed out that code-wise, a multiguild system is somewhat unbalancing with regard to guildskills - should the two be incorporated.  Basically, having code guildskills available to characters in multiple guilds is unfair.  If guildskills are to be re-introduced (as specific coded GUILDskills), we need to figure out how to restrict them in a way that does not limit PC creativity (Gleeman Sedai advisor to a Queen in DD?  Sure, be in all those guilds!) but that does not reward cheesing the system (Warder-trained Aiel Wolfkin? Uh... Signal Veil Wofldream Goldeneyes?  No... thank you...)\n
\n

The old guild system made it impossible to have multiple guildskills, and while I prefer allowing players to be in as many guilds at a time as they can justify, I certainly don't want people having half the guildskills in the game on one character just because they wrote a neat background.\n
\n
`!4) `1Imm trust.`7\n
\n

Zach brought up the point that we, as Imms, have a lot of trust to regain with the players.  Though none of our current (active) staff has really ever abused that trust as far as I know, there is a long history of staff distrust that we have to overcome, because a lot of our players have long memories.  It isn't necessarily fair that we will be held to a standard based on the actions of previous Imms, but we will be, and missteps will serve to reinforce bad feelings on behalf of the playerbase.\n
\n

Overcoming this is simple, but not easy.  First and foremost, we need to say what we mean and mean what we say - basically make promises and keep them.  Secondly, we should be as transparent as possible without endangering plots or player characters.  Third, we should be clear about our boundaries: our immranks should mean what they say and we should each respect the domains of the others - Ayasha is HEAD Building and Story, and has the final say on zones and plotlines, Anazail is HEAD Shadow and has final say on Shadowy stuffs, I've got Guilds and would like final say on Human Resources - but we should all be sharing our (non-secret) stuff with each other because none of it is totally independent.\n
\n

For example, and just because it's a recent one, Ayasha has complete control over who gets bookies (aside from Forsaken), but a head's up to the rest of us so we know that the bookie's taken and by whom lets us look like we're all on the same page - and lets us be prepared to include them.  Doing what we do within our own purviews shouldn't require 'permission' from the others, but we should include each other in our decisions.  So far, this has not been any kind of issue - but it is something to keep in mind, since hoarding domains caused previous Imm staffs a lot of problems with players.\n
\n
OK, those are the major points I wanted to bring up.  None of it is terribly urgent, though channeling would be great, I just want to make sure we're all on the same page.\n
\n
-R\n

Third, we should be clear about our boundaries: our immranks should mean what they say and we should each respect the domains of the others - Ayasha is HEAD Building and Story, and has the final say on zones and plotlines, Anazail is HEAD Shadow and has final say on Shadowy stuffs, I've got Guilds and would like final say on Human Resources - but we should all be sharing our (non-secret) stuff with each other because none of it is totally independent.\n
\n

For example, and just because it's a recent one, Ayasha has complete control over who gets bookies (aside from Forsaken), but a head's up to the rest of us so we know that the bookie's taken and by whom lets us look like we're all on the same page - and lets us be prepared to include them.  Doing what we do within our own purviews shouldn't require 'permission' from the others, but we should include each other in our decisions.  So far, this has not been any kind of issue - but it is something to keep in mind, since hoarding domains caused previous Imm staffs a lot of problems with players.\n
\n
OK, those are the major points I wanted to bring up.  None of it is terribly urgent, though channeling would be great, I just want to make sure we're all on the same page.\n
\n
-R\n
\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Tue Feb 19 09:11:03 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Rissa
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Immly issues
\n`7CC`6: `7Anazail Jaiden Duren Ayasha
\n\n
Couple things I'd like to put on the table to be solved over the next little while as we work to bring code back and get everything in line:\n
\n
`!1) `1Code vs RP exp.`7\n
\n
When code comes back in and exp can be awarded for killing mobs, how will that exp be awarded vs how RP exp will be awarded?\n
\n

On our drive back from Austin, the three of us talked about several different options, including bringing back the separation of code and RP levels.  The main crux was that code levels could be balanced to effectively eliminate the arbitrary assignment of 100 OCS, giving us the ability to make flowstrengths a scale of 1-100 (rather than a 'high' flowstrength being around 40 like right now).  Whether or not exp is all one system for code and RP or if they're split between code and RP levels, the question remains of how to balance RP exp gain with code exp gain, both overall (i.e., does RP award 100exp per emote and code awards 10exp per mob) and as a composite (i.e., how much RP exp = how much code exp *per emote*).\n
\n

Anazail could explain it better because he has a better grasp on the math and a better idea how to balance code and RP exps, but while I really don't personally like the concept of code levels, they made some very persuasive arguments for the reintroduction of that system.\n
\n
`!2) `1Channeling combat.`7\n
\n

I would like to see a system of channeling combat that is less like D&D spells and more like channeling.  Anazail and I have discussed several options - and I think Anazail and Duren have talked about it a little bit, too - and while I know physical combat and the code combat system (along with econ, etc.) are the priorities, eventually I would like to bring channeling combat up to snuff with the rest of it.\n
\n
Included here is the necessity of balancing chan/non-chan combat, including the requirement that the ambush be respected by the code.\n
\n
`!3) `1Multiguilds and Guildskills.`7\n
\n

Last week, Zach and I had a discussion regarding the multiguild system we have right now.  He pointed out that code-wise, a multiguild system is somewhat unbalancing with regard to guildskills - should the two be incorporated.  Basically, having code guildskills available to characters in multiple guilds is unfair.  If guildskills are to be re-introduced (as specific coded GUILDskills), we need to figure out how to restrict them in a way that does not limit PC creativity (Gleeman Sedai advisor to a Queen in DD?  Sure, be in all those guilds!) but that does not reward cheesing the system (Warder-trained Aiel Wolfkin? Uh... Signal Veil Wofldream Goldeneyes?  No... thank you...)\n
\n

The old guild system made it impossible to have multiple guildskills, and while I prefer allowing players to be in as many guilds at a time as they can justify, I certainly don't want people having half the guildskills in the game on one character just because they wrote a neat background.\n
\n
`!4) `1Imm trust.`7\n
\n

Zach brought up the point that we, as Imms, have a lot of trust to regain with the players.  Though none of our current (active) staff has really ever abused that trust as far as I know, there is a long history of staff distrust that we have to overcome, because a lot of our players have long memories.  It isn't necessarily fair that we will be held to a standard based on the actions of previous Imms, but we will be, and missteps will serve to reinforce bad feelings on behalf of the playerbase.\n
\n

Overcoming this is simple, but not easy.  First and foremost, we need to say what we mean and mean what we say - basically make promises and keep them.  Secondly, we should be as transparent as possible without endangering plots or player characters.  Third, we should be clear about our boundaries: our immranks should mean what they say and we should each respect the domains of the others - Ayasha is HEAD Building and Story, and has the final say on zones and plotlines, Anazail is HEAD Shadow and has final say on Shadowy stuffs, I've got Guilds and would like final say on Human Resources - but we should all be sharing our (non-secret) stuff with each other because none of it is totally independent.\n
\n

For example, and just because it's a recent one, Ayasha has complete control over who gets bookies (aside from Forsaken), but a head's up to the rest of us so we know that the bookie's taken and by whom lets us look like we're all on the same page - and lets us be prepared to include them.  Doing what we do within our own purviews shouldn't require 'permission' from the others, but we should include each other in our decisions.  So far, this has not been any kind of issue - but it is something to keep in mind, since hoarding domains caused previous Imm staffs a lot of problems with players.\n
\n
OK, those are the major points I wanted to bring up.  None of it is terribly urgent, though channeling would be great, I just want to make sure we're all on the same page.\n
\n
-R\n

column5: Ragnar, son of Lir, son of Cor, from a tiny hamlet called Hasroth Hall high in the World's End Mountains. Also known as Ragnar Bloodaxe. His childhood was unremarkable for one of his clan, spent mostly helping about with odd jobs, getting in fights and pulling pranks. His mischievous streak was quickly detected and soon became well known in the community. Semi-harmless pranks, pointless fights, drinking and debauchery became a way of life for him, but did not endear him to his neighbors.  Restless and adventurous in nature, he left Hasroth hall in the spring of his fifteenth year to make what fortunes for himself as he could.

column1: \n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Wed Feb 20 00:47:52 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Gwain

\n`7Subj`6:`7 Ragnar, son of Lir, son of Cor, from a tiny hamlet called Hasroth Hall high in the World's End Mountains. Also known as Ragnar Bloodaxe. His childhood was unremarkable for one of his clan, spent mostly helping about with odd jobs, getting in fights and pulling pranks. His mischievous streak was quickly detected and soon became well known in the community. Semi-harmless pranks, pointless fights, drinking and debauchery became a way of life for him, but did not endear him to his neighbors.  Restless and adventurous in nature, he left Hasroth hall in the spring of his fifteenth year to make what fortunes for himself as he could.

\nRags travelled widely and tried his hand at a number of professions and tasks before always moving on to something else soon after beginning.  Roughly four years after starting, he finally came to settle down at the White Tower with the notion of becoming a famed warrior.   The fighting he excelled at, although the lack of discipline significantly hindered his training, find him in hot water more often than not. \n
Even so, Ragnar's training progressed, and by his twenty third year he had completed training at the white tower and found himself bonded to Ealasaid Sedai of the Blue Ajah.\n

The arrangement worked for roughly two years. Although his flighty and undisciplined nature made him rather unsuitable as a warder in the long term, it was a task he took seriously and excelled at in the short term. Or at least, his Aes Sedai didn't die.\n

After three years, though, Ragnar's feet itched to wander again and he and Ealasaid parted ways. Though still bonded, and often silently watching over her from the dream, they have spent the last five years tentatively avoiding one another.\n

It was in the first year of the absence that he began noticing the wolves.  Most of Ragnar's life was spent on the outer edge of society, preferring the lack of laws and lawmen, and upon the road while travelling, and it was here in the woods that he began exploring his connection to the wolves. \n

At first as a flight of fancy, the man had always imagined himself as part bear, akin to the berserkers of old, Ragnar began to track and observe a local wolf pack. It was with this pack that the wolf slowly awakened and grew, and introduced him to others nearby.\n

He has passed through the braem pack on several occasions (perhaps even offering to keep an eye on Liro's niece whenever he's in the White Tower), most recently wintering with them during the long months, but always he eventually moves on.\n
BreezeChaser\n

A lumbering brown wolf cappers and plays amid the dancing shadows cast by a trickster's moon.  Around him, scent and sight blur in confused, disjointed signals around him, his demeanor often at odds with the truth of his scent beneath. A new scent arrives, brought into the glade on a light breeze. The wolf's nose twitches and raises to catch the foreign scent, and soon he is darting off, into the woods, abandoning his play to chase the breeze that carried the new smell.\n
Aethen al'cab or cab'sorei, I figure.\n

I may alter up his wolfsend when I have more time to work with it. It hits the aspects of his personality, of putting on a show of being a fool, and always chasing after the next horizon, but it could do with abit more eloquence. \n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Thu Feb 21 00:08:55 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Ayasha
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Wolfie Quest
\n`7CC`6: `7Tarem Jaiden Anazail Rissa \n
\n
When Eli tore the top off the hill during the quest, I guild-echoed a wolf\n
sending to the wolfies in the area about the incident, in order to provide them\n
a means of getting some RP.  \n

\n`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
\n`7Date`6:`7 Fri Feb 22 22:52:07 2013\n`7From`6:`7 Ailsa
\n`7Subj`6:`7 Gleeman Template
\n`7CC`6: `7Rissa Ailsa
\n\n
\n
`!{`#} `7An in-door life is less `@p`2oetical`7,              `&{`!}\n
`#}`&{    `7And out of door hath `^s`6howers`7, and `&m`7ists,    `!}`1{\n
`#}`!{ `7With which I could not `#b`3rew`7 a pastoral.        `!}`#{\n
`!{`1}    `7But be it as it may, a `%b`5ard`7 must meet       `#{`&}\n
`1}`!{ `7All `!d`1ifficulties`7, whether great or small,      `&}`#{\n
`!{`#}    `7To `@s`2poil`7 his undertaking or complete,       `#{`!}\n
`#}`&{ `7And work away like `&s`7p`8ir`7i`&t`7 upon matter,         `!}`1{\n
`&{`!} `7Embarrass'd somewhat both with `1f`!i`#r`!e`7 and `&w`^a`6t`^e`&r`7. `1{`!}\n
\n
\n
`&What are poets for, in such an age?\n
`7What is the use of poetry?\n
\n
`^G`6l`!e`1e`#m`@e`2n`7 are the traveling minstrels, bards, buskers, and\n
storytellers of the Age. Their signature patchwork cloaks\n
provide them welcome and acclaim wherever they go. The role\n
of entertainer is not an easy one, and the trade is not for\n
the weak of mind, body, or spirit.  But for those few whose\n
passions for enlightenment and enjoyment keep their feet\n
always moving forward and their eyes always looking to the\n
horizon, the trade can be a fulfilling and rewarding one.\n
\n
\n
To gain entrance to the guild of those most honorable souls,\n
the following steps must be undertaken:\n
\n
\n
`!-`1Send your character background and description`7 to the\n
Guildleader.  Once they are approved, you will be recognized\n
as a seeker of the guild.\n
\n
\n
`#-`3Your background should be relatively comprehensive`7 and\n
include not only where your character comes from, but how\n
and why he intends to seek out training to become a `^G`6l`!e`1e`#m`@a`2n`7.\n
`&Note`7 - this may include a lack of a current in character\n
desire to pursue the profession if you wish to have it be\n
unplanned by your character.\n
\n
`@-`2Your background may not include any official training`7\n
toward the patchwork cloak without prior approval from\n
the Guildleader.  Advancement within `^G`6l`!e`1e`#m`@a`2n`7 is\n
accomplished from within the guild, not from without.\n
\n
`^-`6Once approval to seek the guild is granted, you will need\n
to obtain sponsorship`7 from two active members of the guild\n
or the Guildleader directly.\n
\n
`!-`7This does not require "`^G`6l`!e`1e`#m`@a`2n`7 RP", necessarily, since\n
at first your character should not really have the\n
performance accumen to support performance RP.  Much of\n
the sponsorship RP might be obtained with alts of active\n
members, so remember that in addition to being performers,\n
`^G`6l`!e`1e`#m`@e`2n`7 are also the keepers of many disguises and secrets.\n
`!Always RP at the highest level of your ability.`7\n
\n
`#-`3Once sponsored, the Guildleader will speak with you`7 to add\n
your character to the guild and provide an introduction to\n
the syllabus and expectations, both in- and out-of-character,\n
of members of the guild.\n
\n
\n
See the `^G`6l`!e`1e`#m`@a`2n`7 Guildleader or the `%G`5uild `&I`7mmortal with any\n
questions, and happy seeking!\n
